So, but also with such dense populated area you have, like the older people are no longer taken care of within the comfort of their families and friends, now they have to be within social home communities, preservation of land or properties that have character. Yes.

qaPairs.question: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, please. You can guide me through using the system.

qaPairs.question: You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
qaPairs.answer: Sure.

qaPairs.question: For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
qaPairs.answer: Thanks

qaPairs.question: You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, I'm now comfortable.

qaPairs.question: As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
qaPairs.answer: Okay, well noted. Thank you.

qaPairs.question: Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
qaPairs.answer: First question, please.

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: Well, as you mentioned earlier on, about the aspect of affordability and the supply of housing, the aspect of bringing in terms of equity and inclusion of all people, the use of land efficiency and environment, my preference would be against, would be against, rather would be opposing upzoning policies for reasons being every community, every town, every suburb has a character, has a culture, has a history in it. So when that is abruptly changed, the diminishing value, whether it is in economic terms or even just the structural, infrastructure of that particular town or city, there's a lot of things that need to be rearranged, for example, talk about water systems, the sewer systems, power, because with upzoning, you'd have an influx of people moving into a low zone area and that becomes a highly densely populated. So I believe it would take time to have a systematic phase that would ensure that that particular area and zone doesn't feel overwhelmed or doesn't feel, the feel and the look of the town won't feel imposed upon, that even the locals themselves, those ones who are born there, who do business there, would ease into the gradual bringing of new people, opening of businesses, changing of the character of a town. So if it was a quaint family or quaint farming kind of town and now you've changed it to an upscale zoned region now that becomes commercial or school-based, the very nature and culture and the history of the town changes. So that would be one of my reasons. I think also how, okay, apart from that, the outlook of a town, the way the layout had been set, it would really change the own homeowners, the mindset, especially if you had people who are settling in for life, either they had estates or properties they had bought for life. So with that kind of changing of upzoning policies and bringing higher density of housing, it would change the value of the property, and not just in terms of financial, but also in terms of functionality and use. So those would just be one of the reasons why I would oppose the upzoning policies that are for higher density housing, especially in traditional single homes neighbourhood.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: Well, the most significant impacts, of course, would be the positive, those who are for the increase of the housing density within residential neighbourhoods, because now you have an influx of people coming in, so the profile of the town gets to change, even the economic activity changes. If it's in terms of government policy, you have more people who are catered for in terms of housing and meeting of housing needs. Then the aspect of, the concept of equity in terms of sharing of resources in terms of now, so if you have a uniform set of homes, water, power, gas, yeah, they'll be shared across, it'll be easy to do planning and you know, within this particular town, within this particular neighbourhood, this is the ratio or this is the amount of resources that are needed. So, with that also, in terms of government planning, you're able to know, with this area, a particular zone, you have an expectation of maybe 50 to 80 families, so you're able to set in planning for medical facilities, school facilities, fire, fighting, and you're able to know, within a certain jurisdiction or geographical area, how much of that resource will be needed and how to reallocate resources or needs, yes. And then also, the aspect of the land ratio, the efficiency of using that land, smaller portions of land is able to accommodate a large number of people, yeah.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: It would affect the housing affordability in urban areas because now you've got an increase in volume and the supply is high and the demand will be created, so definitely the cost of rental will go down, cost of valuation in terms of ownership will also go down and yeah.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer: Well, that would definitely change if at the onset you had a quiet neighborhood, family-oriented, single family, so you have zoned out sections that are for maybe a quaint home with a compound and play designated areas for children, less traffic within the streets, so safety and you'd have a certain age group that are able to walk without supervision. The neighborhood is small, so you're able to know who your neighbors are and interact with them, also in terms of community welfare. So with increased housing density on a neighborhood, the character changes because now it becomes more commercial-based, fast-paced, you've got more neighbors, so chances of you not knowing most of your neighbors are high. With that also, we talk about, it will touch on quality of life because now you're having a diversity of characters coming in, so increased in terms of insecurity, crime, regulation of laws, movement, traffic, it would touch on a lot. It would really affect the character coming from a single family neighborhood to one that is upscaled through the housing density program.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: Yes, like mentioned earlier, so you'd have to cater for planning services to ensure that there'll be expansion of road and road networks, manage aspects to do with traffic conjecture and systems, parking facilities, and also if you're going to have new bus routes or zones where you strictly either allow buses or trams to be able to accommodate the huge influx of the number of people and cater for public transportation and private.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: So, local governments are key in this particular aspect, in terms of before the aspect of deployment, they should be in a place whereby they are able to do research, come up with proposals, timelines, look at the environmental impact assessment of the pros and cons of having such a change within a certain area, and also really balance to know if the services, if the weight of the services that are already existing within this particular neighbourhood will be able to handle such an influx, and if not, what kind of transitional phase would take in terms of what period or investment or national government involvement to ensure that there is a seamless flow, or as much as there is an influx of increased density and number of people within this developed area, but also it matches and maps with what the local government is able to offer in terms of services. So, whether it be through the medical, through the fire and the social community ones, or through the government services, every aspect should be taken into consideration. So, proper planning, proper planning beyond just the theory and paper, but also being able to do mappings and assessments. Yes.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: Well, the environment will definitely be impacted. You're having a low-density area now becoming high-density, so in terms of planning, in terms of natural park spaces, environmentally located lands whereby we just create green spaces rather than becoming a concrete jungle, those are things that need to be factored in. Even aspects to do with waste management, both for litter and just house, those have to be taken into consideration. And yes, the increment of emissions and the waste will definitely increase the size and the population of the area, so those are things that need to be factored in.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: So, for the positive, you'd have more influx of diversity of businesses or income-generating activities within this high-density zone coming into play. And with that, you've got a high turnover of currency, money exchange, value of properties going up, a flurry of activities that do support the commercial activity, the commercial lifestyle â€“ that would be the positive side. The negative side would be as much as you have the increase in economic activity, now the downside would be on the negative side of fraud, stealing or fraudulent activities. Those things that come in with the expansion of a certain mindset or a certain exchange of flow of currency, the negative aspects would come into being also. So also you'd have illegal activities in terms of commercial businesses that would be within the range. But overall, I think the positive will not be the negative because now you have got exposure to different kind of lifestyle, of different kind of expectation, different kind of businesses because now you've got an influx of people coming in with different interests and different area of trades and the needs and supplies, needs of the people within this area are diverse. So if it was a single-based family, rural quaint kind of environment that would only deal with food, farming, timber yard, now you'd have warehouses that come in, you would have clothing stores coming in, game park, arcades, coffee shops, having interactive even telecommunication companies just to deal with the influx and the needs of locals.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: So, I believe the current residents, there needs to be a collaborative or an understanding between the current residents, the current residing residents of this region, and most likely have a zoned proposal to have a section maybe of a town become the high-density area and another zone just remain low-density, but have the current residents given the input in terms of those who will be willing to get into the program, those who will not be willing to get into the program, factor in those who have been in the land or property for, if it's inheritance that has been passed on from several generations, what will be the impact of changing that kind of zoning, what kind of businesses that this kind of current residents are currently employed at, if it's agricultural, what will be the long-term effect of subdividing or turning, converting agricultural land into a high-density commercial zone in the long run in terms, just looking at the economic, the future economic outlook of this town versus what has been proposed, what are the things that could be sacrificed and other things that have to be maintained even for the character and the stature of the particular town. Also in consideration of bringing in the future residents, the current residents would also have a say in terms of what kind of town would they be aspiring in terms of being, would it be a technological one, educational one, would it just be a multi-user, or it could be a specialized kind of zone. So they'd have a chance to do that so that when you have the future residents, you'd have probably, if it's through a lottery pool or a particular set of selection, that it matches what the current residents own, matches what has been zoned and planned for this high-density area.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: The conversation about social equity would bring about diversity of people and classes within this neighbourhood. So, it would be great to make it open that people of all colours, race and creed would find a habitable, hospitable environment, a place of living within such a zoning or housing area. And also, it would cater for the elderly and the young, and also depending on the scale in terms of economic power. So, whether it's the middle class or working class, those ones who are below the middle class, that within this particular zone, everyone, whoever comes in, they're able to profile themselves and see that they do fit in. They're not excluded or denied access to utility or interest within the zone because of either financial incapability or particular preference of race. Yeah.

The app zoning policies support usually are not immediate. For it to be effective, effectively implemented, effectively rolled out, effectively impacting the community, it does take time to develop. With that, that will be a positive thing because now it gives the locals and the town to either grow into it, or look into all manner of ways or ideas, or consider factors that are not considered before, and ensure that every form of planning that can be done is either documented, discussed, put at the table, and clearly planned out for or mapped up for. That is on the positive side. On the negative side, it will be such a thing, such a policy. If it does take so much time, it becomes a priority to the community whereby there was a plan, maybe the community was on board, but it never comes to maturation, especially having elected leadership who come in and go out within a certain tenure. Before the next authority office comes in and is able to take the same document, or able to take the same policy, and really try to implement, so there will always be a restart, always going back to restart the project, to restart the project, and never really get to the place of materializing it. With that also, you've got missed times in terms of allocation of resources and finances, and also, what would you call it, not material gain, but intellectual or resourceful personnel, resourceful assistance that would have been during a certain period of time that was not there before.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Upzoning Policies on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Upzoning Policies â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, for various reasons, main causes are normally for increased, getting increased in terms of housing when there's a housing crisis or shortage of housing. And with that, if you have an area that has that, maybe the long-term plan is to have maybe a commercial industrial facility or a school zone facility. So, having an upzone area gets to cater for the speculated or forecasted upsurge of people coming into the town. So, with that, so it brings the aspect of equity in terms, let's say if it's a school or a campus town or a campus zone area, so you've got the aspect of bringing equity in terms of getting housing within the student areas or the student zones, or if it's within a commercial industrial complex or town or city, you've got the influx of numbers, but also people coming into work are able to get affordable housing at a very equitable, friendly and accessible way. So, also for, in the same way, in terms of mobility and the economic growth of the town, mobility would be, you've brought the homes now closer to the schools or home closer to the working environment. So, whether it would be increased in terms of movement of vehicles through traffic or walking pedestrians or use of bikes, but the accessibility and accessibility of the people into those particular facilities that they needed for that particular time, those are part of the positive one. For the negative one, coming from single-family neighbourhoods, like I mentioned before, you have to consider if some of these families were generational in terms of inheritance from generations past. So, what happens when such areas or such cities or urban places are converted to high-density up-zoning sections, that value, that emotional attachment of value to that land shifts. So you'd have probably a gap in terms of, or a cut-out in terms of the value and the history of the land. So, and even just the belief of the people, because now you have diversity and multiplicity of people coming in from different backgrounds, different interests all over town. So even you find a history of a particular place disappears. So those are just some of the negative effects of the support for the up-zoning.
qaPairs.question: What do you think are the main causes of Support for Upzoning, and how certain are you about these relationships? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: So, this particular question can be looked at in different ways. You'd have uninitialized upzoning pre-unidentified or established economic activity that would change the nature of the area. Or you'd have the economic activity coming into place and changing the nature of demand of this particular zone area to become now to be part of a zone that's matter for upzoning. So for example, you'd have a school campus built or a commercial manufacturing plant or assembly plant and that would cause the economic activity of that area to change and cause a demand for consideration for upzoning of a region. So because now you'd have workers or students who have to come to this particular facility for work or for access to services and either for efficiency or convenience to get housing within a certain region, those kind of facilities need to be put in place. So that's how I put it in terms of that question. So does it have a positive effect, increasing or negative effect? And how strong is this effect? So in terms of changes of economic activity changes, yes, it has probably positive effects. Like I mentioned earlier, you have now an increased influx of people within this particular region. And on the matters of economics of supply and demand, not beyond just the basic needs, but also extending beyond the basic needs to now increase in grocery stores, increases service providers, increase in also meeting niche kind of services that were not there before, because you've got an influx of people who have different eclectic tastes coming into town, diversity of food tastes and eateries, just to cater for the different classes and different needs of the people. So the negative effect is now the population has increased. It's no longer the friendly neighborhood where you know your neighborhood and you're able to keep tracks about what is missing, who's happening, what's happening. And now crime, susceptibility of crime and safety within the neighborhood has to be checked in. So with that, you'll have increased policing or government surveillance. And also with that, you'd have a lot of traffic movement in terms of people coming in and out of the towns, even out of towns, even if you don't live there. So how strong is this effect? As long as there are people and there's demand, there's supply and there's movement and there's an environment that causes them to do the activities they need to do without really going out, it will change. It will change the economic activity of a particular town. In fact, change the character and the nature or even history of that particular area.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Economic activity changes lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Economic activity changes â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, generally, it would have an effect on the support for upzoning. On the positive note, you've got an influx of a number of housing needs to be constructed, so on the positive note would be increase of job market in terms of masonry construction. And even with the zoning policy, we'd probably talk about the quality of the housing infrastructure, if they'll be uniform or not, in terms of lighting, patterns, painting, the whole aspect of planning. And beyond just the construction of the homes, you've got the sewer system, the water system, the architectural, in terms of the layout of the land, the road structures, in terms of accessibility of the homes and the social amenities that are needed. So on the positive, you've got a flurry of economic activities that will bring an influx of people in, even economic in terms of financial gain. And then property value itself, what would have stood with one particular house of property, now you've got a multi-storey building that is able to cater for different home owners, so bank, credit, collateral, businesses, or other, even the economic value of the land would go up. So on the negative, moving for a single house, single family neighbourhood, probably have natural trees, zoned out sections of forest, so it becomes more of a concrete jungle than a green, preserved environment. And also, you have to factor in those social amenities very well, so that you don't have lesser shortages of natural resources, in terms of water, or the sewer systems, or the gas. Yeah. And, yeah, ensure the infrastructure that is needed to ensure that such kind of houses that are able to cater for that number of people are met effectively, yes.
qaPairs.question: Does Increase in housing supply have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Increase in housing supply â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, it does affect the relationship between loss of familiarity among neighbours and support of us, upzoning. In the single-family neighbourhood, you have a situation whereby neighbours form lifelong relationships that is passed on from parents to children and can go on for generations. But with such kind of environments where you bring an influx through upzoning, the turnover of neighbours could be as high as maybe depending on the contracts or if it's a school zone, finishing up a particular course. So having those kind of deep, bonding, community kind of relationships are difficult unless the individuals, the neighbours are determined or deliberate in working to such kind of relationships. And the care, the community warmth that was there before with the single-family neighbourhoods will not be there in such a zone because now the influx has gone up. The majority of people who are coming into these particular zones are coming for work and activity, flurry of activity, so everyday they engage meeting other people. So unless now your relationship is based on your relationship in terms of your commercial activity or social activity that is sustaining you or keeping you within that town. So in terms of positive effect, it's easy. You can connect to someone from another state or from another culture, from another family, from another race, a background that you never had and create this eclectic, multicultural bond with another family that you probably would not have imagined. But on the negative side, you create superficial relationships that have no life bond or literally just superficial and such communities are fickle and they die out. So with that, even you'd consider if there were older people in the community, the care that they would want to experience, they'll probably not get it in such a kind of town. Thank you for watching.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Loss of familiarity among neighbors and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Loss of familiarity among neighbors â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, expansion of road networks will definitely be a must, as long as there is an upsurge of housing or accommodation areas as part of requirement in terms of land laws, the aspect of way lives, so access roads, alleys, so that the people within the neighbourhood are able to access their homes or access the immediate needed community facilities, so network of such roads needs to be considered. Also with an influx of people, you would have influx of the modes of transportation, whether it's through bikes, skating, if it's through motor vehicle private ownership or through one to public means. So even in some places, probably even trams, so expansion of that communication road network would have to be planned for, would have to be considered. Does it have a positive? Yes, it has a positive because now you've answered one need of the people is to get housing, the other need will be giving them convenient and access at a very fast time or affordable time and adding more to the convenience of having moved to this higher zoned region. In terms of negative effect, the planning of the road needs to be done before the construction of the houses that you will make sure you have enough way live area, whether it be a double single roads, considering factors to do pedestrian walking areas and bike sites and also greenery that is around the road area needs to be factored in also. So those are things that need to be factored in and to know what kind of areas that would have high traffic, that would be the negative aspect. Gridlocks in terms of traffic, that area that didn't have traffic before would have taken you 15 minutes, now it's taking 30 minutes. Cost of public transportation, noise pollution and even CO2 emissions, noise pollution in terms of honking, car movements and then also if you factor in light pollution because if you're living near the road or near the highway, the lights that would always be there would be affecting you. Yeah I think that's what I'll say for now.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Expansion of road networks and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Expansion of road networks â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Research and planning does have both positive and negative and it's essential for support of app zoning. The aspect of app zoning through the planning and research is what gives the basis, it gives the anchorage and the argument, the landing base argument, for why the need for the support for the app zoning in that particular region. It gives the blueprints, it gives the map, it gives the timelines, it gives you the environmental impact assessment, it gives you reports on what will work, what will not work, and if the plan still goes ahead, what can be done to either mitigate or change the cause of that particular action. So planning is really, really important. It's something that cannot be overlooked in app zoning. It has to be theoretically documented and also, it's like a way through mind reading, you're able to go through the specific phases or the steps that have been agreed on and see how to implement it. And also, even to the point of the interest of researchers to take case studies of what has worked, if bringing an upsurge of population in one area to another, how will it affect the other towns around, how will it affect the infrastructure that is there within, what needs to be added, what needs to be removed, what considerations need to be taken so that the people, the local government, the environment itself, everything within that area would feel catered for.
qaPairs.question: Does Research and Planning have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Research and Planning â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, one of the greatest conclusions and one of the greatest fights between neighborhoods that have single-family neighborhoods, suburbans, and the transition to move into a zoned, up-zoned area is the aspect that you change the nature and the character of land and environment, one from greenery nature into a concrete jungle. So, one of the ways that that can be carved in or rather worked on, I know in the past it was such an argument that we put in, but now with the kind of planners and architects that we have, they're able to incorporate the built and the nature in the designs. So, having as much as it's a concrete jungle but have natural aspects that blend in with the environment so that the outlook is not just we're putting up apartments or putting up houses to meet the needs of people, this concrete jungle, but creating an environment that's sustainable, creating an environment that is inviting, creating an environment that extends the greenery or the environment of this particular land. So, in terms of negative, yes, you don't have the aspect of fresh air, some sections of building will never experience sunlight because you're covered with this concrete wall, the coldness and dampness of death definitely, we mentioned even getting sick and diseases, yeah, and because it's a concrete jungle you'd have a high influx of reliance and gas for heating up and warming up homes. So, for the positive effect, it's a way of bringing, they can be able to bring in positive or bring in creative ways of combining technology in build and design, mixing what is called of nature and that which is of concrete and come up with something that's homage to both the environment, both the greenery and the building of the need of building an up-zoning region so that you have this neighbourhood that captures both the beauty of the jungle, concrete jungle and nature and is inviting even to be a spectacle for people who don't live there. Yes.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Concrete jungle and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Concrete jungle â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So income generating activities would definitely increase, like we said earlier, the impacts of having a diversity and variety of people coming in, the supply and demand of the basic needs that they need in terms of their living existence or the living expenses or utilities that they need. Also, each one of them has a particular preference and hobby, so a flurry of new economic activities, income generating activities would come in support of this upzoning area. So depending if it's a school zone, there are a lot of things, there's also go hiking, camping, arts, computers, those are business ideas also for every need that the people need. That is also, the answer is in the business model that supplies, so the demand for certain products or certain services which are met by businesses or businesswomen who are willing to offer the services in those communities. So the aspect of upzoning increases the economic activity within a particular jurisdiction. If before that particular land was locked in maybe strictly horticultural farming, but now because of the demand you'd have to put up farmer's market, you'd have to put a cant business for the fruits, drinks, honey, diversity of activity and flurry, and that demand is there within the town. The demand, the need for those resources is there for that town. So I see it as a positive effect that increases, yes.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Income-generating activities and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Income-generating activities â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Wow, this is interesting. So for high density zone areas, support for upzoning is a welcome, is a welcome feat because now you're sure they'll be brought on the table, the aspect of the supply rather than the demand. The demand is for high for housing. So through the upzoning, because the stages you have to go through the research, the planning phases, prepare, but also you have to factor in the numbers of people. So this particular factor, this particular function will be really welcome because now you're bringing the aspect of increase of housing facility and structures, equity, equity, equity with more houses, you've got more people being able to either afford a unit or even get like a dignified, a dignified facility, a dignified home with a set standard that has been set within the local government. Also with the high density zones, it will be, it would unburden overcrowding in buildings, safety measures, and bring about the aspect of planning in terms of national planning in terms of the population. And you're able to forecast within this number of years, this is what will need to be upgraded, this is what needs to be removed. And also with that, if you bring about the aspect of upzoning within high density, the cost of rent also could go down because now the demand, the demand has gone, the supply has gone up, so it's not as scarce thing as it was when it was a high density zone, yes, in terms of getting a house.
qaPairs.question: Does High-density zones have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: High-density zones â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, the collaboration between the current and future residents, you'd have different scenarios. You could have the current residents also, as much as they approve the upzoning of a region, in terms of securing the neighbourhood or the structure and the nature and the character of the neighbourhood, can have deeds of agreement within the communities of what can be done within this community. So, with that, it locks a future resident to a certain class, a certain nature, to a certain standard, to a certain way of life that matches to that environment and matches to the needs of that particular zone per phase, until maybe the next leader comes on board. Also, it gives the current owners a sort of security knowing there'll be no abrupt, shocking changes to the nature and character of the town or the land. And if they had any form of investment, land investment deals or land investment agreements, they get to prepare beforehand in terms of the valuation of the property and whether they're gaining currency or losing currency. Yeah, so, apart from that, also, future residents also are aware that they're able to spark into ownership or spark into belonging to a certain community, either based on the laws or the regulations set by the current ones, or if the current ones have left it open, that they know they have a responsibility to take care of that environment and honour the current residents or even the older residents who've been there before the change of the zone going on.
qaPairs.question: Does Collaboration between current and future residents have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Collaboration between current and future residents â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Yes, like I said earlier, the rule is it can either proceed or come afterwards. So if the opportunity proceeds, let's say an opportunity for an investor who wants to set up a multi-million dollar tech facility and the level of employment will be a certain calibre of number of people, that opportunity leads to changes in supporting of the up-zoning. Or vice versa, if it's a scientific facility like the Shinobi that had a leak, nuclear leak, that had to require that people leave, so it really depends on the situation. But in both they do affect the access, the changes to the access to the opportunity. So in terms of support of the up-zoning areas.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Access to Opportunity lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Access to Opportunity â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So where there is an influx or an upzone area, definitely we'd have an upsurge of diversity of people, diversity of working class or socio-economic classes, diversity of tribes, nations, diversity of personalities, diversity of functions. So it has a great significant effect because it changes the cultural outlook of the people of this town, language changes, communication changes, business money changes. The negative effect now is the lack of balance in terms of what is communally agreed upon unless the community comes in through the water. So I would say that electoral leaders are diversity of thoughts and interests and diversity of morals in terms of what people consider ethical, non-ethical. Yes, that's what I would say.
qaPairs.question: Does Diversity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Diversity â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Yes, the little things are what make the bigger picture. So, the devil's in the details. So, when it comes to up-zoning policies, the policies have to be well-researched and planning has to be on point and every factor that can be considered, even in terms of change, needs to be factored in. One of the ways you could have is through public participation and you have the locals or through the leaders or sub-leaders go through like a drill mock-up and say, we need to consider this, we need to consider this, we need to consider this, we need to consider this. So, you can have at least a zone that is standing whether beyond the new constitution or the new laws that everyone's mind is on the document, everyone's input is on the document, it's planned out, it's prepared, we're prepared by all.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Effectiveness of Upzoning Policies lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Effectiveness of Upzoning Policies â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: So, in a community, they'll tell you to look at the diversity. So, if you go back to the single-family youth neighbourhood, the community character would be one seamless, and you'd have a mix of having the young and the old, and the middle-aged living in one community, and life flows on. When you bring the aspect of up-zoning a region, the influx of the different age groups, the different interests per person, per person will be very different, because now everyone comes with their mindset, their thoughts, what they consider ethical, not ethical, their morality, and collectively what shapes a community is a collection of the members of our community. So, when you have the up-zoned area, the mindset should shift to encapsulating all forms of people, their beliefs, their understanding, their tolerance, and all these affect the community character. So, but also with such dense populated area you have, like the older people are no longer taken care of within the comfort of their families and friends, now they have to be within social home communities, preservation of land or properties that have character. Yes.

qaPairs.question: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
yes
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I support it because, it promotes diversity in that economically it allows for more income and socially it gives room for more schools, different services and it creates job opportunities for people.Another reason would be addressing the issue of housing shortage, the more the houses the less the housing costs and house supply is abundant.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

Affordability has got to be the number one, the other is more housing units meet the demands of customers which is a positive outcome, while the are positive outcomes we cannot lack negative ones which include loss of neighborhood character, overwhelmed infrastructure and it could also lead to increased traffic and parking concerns. It is a double edged sword.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

One of the major effects would be increasing the supply which meets the demands of the customers, this will mean less rent and pricing of houses.It also encourages diversity while also bringing in a few limitations like slow timing because all the plans take time to be implemented, nevertheless some people might even be displaced.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

It can have both positive and negative impacts.To start with, the positive there will be a lot of diversity in terms of culture, mix of people and the negative part would be strain on the available infrastructure, traffic and more noise, displacement is also a possibility.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
It will increase the traffic and will lead to more introduction of alternative means of transport. Great problem for business minded people.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

It should set up policies to govern the whole process, it should also be part of the development so as to ensure affordability of housing, it should be there to improve the infrastructure with the up zoning.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
While there is a lot of awareness creation it all depends on the place, climate change which is a major factor should be mitigated, land should be conserved and sustainable activities implemented,
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
As mentioned earlier affordability and more houses in supply, better economic activities due to increased revenue, the negative ones would include, displacement ,strain of infrastructure usage,
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

Balancing both of these could be quite a task as both would want equity.That is where the policies come in and the ones drafting the policies should look carefully into both groups .All benefits and losses should be shared, longterm solutions to community issues should be raised.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
They both play a central role as social equity matters in correcting previous injustices ,ensuring resources are fairly distributed and allows for affordable housing.

Does Economic benefits have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would say the effects are mainly positive ,house affordability, job creations, high economic growth but it also has negative impacts which would include raised taxes.This effects are moderate and could not hinder the growth of a place in this case, up zoning.

Would small changes in Housing shortage lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
They would be noticeable but not easily . The effects would be minimal .More shortages lead to a positive influence but it all depends with how you relate with the situation at hand.

How confident are you that changes in Meeting customer demand lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am quite confident that meeting customer demand lead to changes in support for up zoning. When up zoning happens more houses means community needs are met and less cost. The effect is moderate in my view.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Believing in the system .The effect and influences are significant and positive.

Does Reduced housing costs have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a positive impact as there will be more business as a result, it plays a big role in the community involved and leads to affordability.

Does Increased traffic have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Increased traffic is a negative because it means people have to stay on the road longer and it could also led to increased crime rate.It could lead to chaotic city and disorganized community. If done right it would be less restrictive.

How confident are you that changes in Policies for housing development lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I am fairly confident. I tend to think that it has a positive effect, that if well taken care of could be a source of good change in the involved community.

How confident are you that changes in Climate change lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I am highly confident, this is because the more people there are in a given area the higher the chances of climate change occurrence, this would have a negative impact on the area and it could sometimes be very adverse.

Would small changes in Land conservation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Not much in my view, if there are right policies put in place and implemented, it could build public trust, the effects on it would be minor if the changes are small and vice versa.

How would you describe the relationship between Infrastructure strain and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

When infrastructure is already under pressure the public will definitely oppose up zoning because of worsening traffic, crowds and shortage of utilities. If infrastructure is adequate then up zoning will easliy be done.The impact would definitely be negative and would have a strong effect.In short if there is infrastructure strain it will be negative impact

Would small changes in Displacement lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
No. The effect is generally negative and it is not noticeable.

Does Policies have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Yes, when the right policies are put in place up zoning will definitely work and for the better.If there are well crafted policies, it will have a greatly positive impact and it will lead to economic growth and a well crafted community.

How would you describe the relationship between Correcting Previous Injustices and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I would say the relationship is still growing, it includes progressive policy makers and equity focused individuals or groups, the effect is positive and it is strong in progressive environments but poses a challenge in weaker environments mostly with conservative individuals or settings.

How confident are you that changes in House affordability lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It is because if there is affordability the possibility of people embracing it are higher as they will pay less rent and experience utilities from within. The change is positive and the effect is quite strong as it could change a whole community.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Promotes diversity, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Affordable housing ,anti discrimination enforcement, these effects are significant because they are long term ,they shape who gets to live where and for generations.The influences are positive.

Is the effect of Positive impact on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It definitely takes time after the policies are made they have to start implementing each with time which all comes to being after a period of time.The policies should be well crafted and assigned their designated time of implementation.It has a positive effect and should reflect strongly when implemented in the right way of course.

Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
ok
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I think it's a good idea in areas that don't have enough housing. So if it's in a high rise building, that way you can get a lot more people in that one small area of the apartment building. And you see apartment buildings everywhere, so I see no problem with having them in a single family neighborhood. Usually there are nice people and there's apartment buildings everywhere that just might not be in that neighborhood, so I see no reason not to do it.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

It gives people who need affordable housing the ability to live in a nice neighborhood and not some poor rundown area that hasn't been developed. So it increases diversity and social cohesion in cities so that people learn to get along with people who aren't in their income bracket and that helps with social cohesion in areas.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

Hopefully, it lowers it because people need affordable housing so that they're not homeless. And in urban areas, it's usually expensive because the location is near a lot of businesses and activities that people go to, so it's more expensive, I think. So it helps lower cost for housing for people because they may have to have a car or a bus to transport them to work, which could be farther away than in the urban areas. And that makes it more expensive unless people would want to live there in the suburban areas because they need transportation.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

I think it would make it more diverse and allow people to see other people who they may not normally see and learn that they are a lot more like them and they are different and so that all income brackets should be living in the same areas so that there is diversity and people understand people more when they see them and aren't separated from them and it helps people with lower incomes have a better quality of life instead of being colonized in a small poor area because of their income level which does not increase happiness or help them grow in income or in life in general.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

It might make traffic more, so there needs to be maybe more roads built, and that is anywhere that is growing, the roads have to be upkept anyway, so they can just widen roads or increase or change roads just like they normally do anyway.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

They should play a big role because they are the ones that are over this area, that locality, so the local government needs to play a big role in learning how much development can increase and how much roads can take, and they need to have engineers to study that because that's what their job is, is to manage the area and help the people have a nice and affordable way of life.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
There needs to make sure that the sewage and water and roads can handle this growth, and if not, do things that are needed to be able to handle it.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
With more people, you have more businesses opening up, which creates more jobs and causes the economy to grow in that area. So it's probably a good thing.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think the current residents should have a say-so also, and future residents will probably not have much of a say-so because they're not even there yet, so the current residents need to be considered because they may not want the growth in that area. They want to keep the natural beauty of the area and the grounds and the forest or whatever natural environment needs to be considered also. So they should have a big say in that, and if they don't want a lot of growth, then maybe the growth should be cut back to a smaller degree.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

There needs to be a big social equity and access to opportunity considered because there are people living there, and they have to have a home, and they have to have opportunity to grow, places to play, places to enjoy their area, too, so that they're not living in a run-down area also. So all people need to have certain things in life to have a good quality of life, so that needs to be considered, too, and they need to have studies done to make sure people with lower incomes have just as many opportunities as people who have more money.

Is the effect of Upzoning policies on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it takes time to develop and it has to implement some ideas and see if they work, how they're working out, study them. It should have a positive effect on people's lives if you're trying to improve their lives and making sure that the negatives are mitigated as they move along and make sure the studies done are correct. And it should have a strong positive effect on people's lives if they have some place safe and clean to live and with close to opportunities to help everyone grow.
What factors affect Support for Upzoning, and which ones have the strongest influence? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

of it. The governments, local governments need to allow the public to have a residence there to have a say in it and explain to them what good things can come of this and that there will be things in place to make sure that there are no negative effects that would affect someone, the people already living there, in a negative way and what they would do if they found negative things happening and what they would do in those instances to help the people already living there understand what's going on.

Would small changes in Neighborhood Development lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

A small change could start out to be a good idea so that you will see if there are negative things going on and then you can stop it right there before major things have already taken place and you can't really undo them. So I would say small things would be better to start out with to see how it's going and then study that and then add some more things to see how positive that is going on in order to not have something majorly negative and then you can't undo it.

How would you describe the relationship between Housing affordability and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Housing affordability helps people have a better quality of life and have a better living area that is safe and clean and the support for upzoning, I'm not sure how that is connected. I'm sure having a housing affordable makes everyone feel less stressed out, having more money in your pocket to be able to live and survive and afford food and take care of your kids so people are happier and not desperate for money and causing people to do things that they wouldn't normally do like steal or do drugs in order to not be stressed out or to avoid this horrible situation they're in that they can't get out of because they don't have enough money. So there should be things like basic income, affordable housing, food for people so that they are not doing things that they wouldn't do normally.

Does Neighborhood diversity have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

diversity is always a good thing because you learn how other people cultures live and it makes you feel more compassion for your neighbor and for other people when you know how that they are just not different than you they may have different things that they do but they're basically people are the same and diversity increases your intelligence when you live with other people and learn their cultures you understand and and are more intelligent when you have a diverse neighborhood or town or area

Would small changes in Traffic Congestion lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Small changes, making the road easier to travel and so people aren't stuck traveling, being stuck in traffic all day, that can be stressful. So you could probably just go with the bigger changes, like making the larger, making more bridges and more wider roads and that, and would to alleviate congestion is a big thing because you don't want to be stuck in traffic for two hours just to go 20 miles. That causes anger and stress in people so they want the roads fixed and they should be fixed.

Would small changes in Housing Development Regulation lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Probably wouldn't notice small changes, probably would take larger shifts. You need to go ahead and build the housing quickly so people aren't in bad situations that they shouldn't be in because of gouging of rent in the area because big banks from New York are coming in and buying up all the land and gouging people for rent and not caring about the area. We need governments to not allow hedge funds and banks to come in and buy up all the property and gouge people. That has to be stopped and allow for affordable housing and the federal government to make sure that the land isn't being bought nefariously, secretly by government officials in the areas that are taking bribes to allow gouging of the public and overbuilding and overselling of land that should be local and used for other purposes that the people need.

Would small changes in Road Infrastructure lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't know, I think you should do larger shifts in roads because people need roads quickly and it takes a long time for the roads to be done. So a larger shift might have a more positive effect of decreasing traffic and other things related to not having good roads.

Would small changes in sewage infrastructure lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I just assume that people have, you have to have the sewage in place before you build. And we should, the public should be informed about what's being built, instead of it secretly being built with no oversight of the public, the public needs to know what the local governments are doing. There needs to be more transparency about who they are selling land to, what they are allowing to go on behind closed doors, who's building what, what's coming up, then the people can have a say so and maybe vote on it instead of these secret deals behind closed doors by corrupt politicians.

Is the effect of Population increase on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I don't know, if the population is very large, then there needs to be roads built and housing built for these people, but not gouging apartment buildings that are being allowed by these big corporations to gouge people, and that people can't even afford the housing. These are just hedge funds within corporations and banks that have so much money that they're using from other people's, other towns, 401ks, they're just spending it any way they can and gouging people, and that can't happen, so that's a negative effect. So that is a strong negative effect, and that should be stopped.

How would you describe the relationship between Control of growth and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

There needs to be engineers to answer that question so that people know what is possible, what is not possible, and what the problem is. Engineers need to study that, scientists need to study that, people don't exactly know what that is better or not, so the government officials need to study that, get the information, give it to the public, and let them decide.

How confident are you that changes in Access to Opportunity lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Not confident at all because I'm not a scientist or an engineer and I don't know the positive effect. It sounds like some of it's positive, better roads, better housing. That's got to have a positive effect. Negative is if you put too much housing in one area and there's not enough roads to handle it. So make sure your roads and your sewage is there in place. And then so that there's not backed up traffic and too many people in one area. It needs to be spread out, I would assume. I don't know.

the relationship between quality of life and resort. There's gotta be a large relationship and a connection. People have a better quality of life and a good place to live. There's gotta be a strong connection. If you have a nice, safe place to live that you can afford and that you can afford the rent and the rent should only take about a quarter of your income, I would think. And so the rest of it can be spent on, you have to have transportation, you have to have food, you have to be able to afford other things and not allow these big corporations to come in and gouge people with rent. That should not be allowed by governments.

lower prices but more crowded.

No.
