Okay.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Let's do it.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I'd have to say that I am somewhat in favor of it because we're currently experiencing a housing crisis and people need homes.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
The most significant impact would be that there'd be more affordable housing for people who are in need of homes.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
I'd like to think that it would make homes in urban areas more affordable.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
I think it could be good for the neighborhood and the character of the neighborhood. I think that having more people
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
I think it would actually hurt transportation quite a bit, at least until the services can accommodate the increased number of people.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

I think local government has to make sure that the different services such as transportation services, such as public schools, are going to be able to accommodate the influx of new people in the neighborhood because of the different housing opportunities.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

To be quite honest, I think it would probably be quite bad for the environment. Having more people in a smaller congested area can't be good for the environment, but I think that the need for homes and the need for people to have affordable homes is a little more pressing than the current environmental concerns.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
I think it would be good for local businesses.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think making any kind of major change to a place where people have been used to living has to be approached with caution because people generally don't like change and you really have to take that into account when making decisions that people have little to no say in.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

I think one of the biggest issues facing people facing economic issues or equity issues is having access to affordable homes. You can't, or rather, people in general can't not have a home to live in. It's of the utmost importance to have any kind of opportunity in life. The most important thing is to have a place that you can live.

How would you describe the relationship between Upzoning policies and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think that the policies can positively affect support for upzoning if it seems like the rules are fair for everybody involved. Like I said before, having little to no say in the decision ultimately will make people feel uneasy about these kinds of changes. I think that some compromises will have to be made because the last thing you want is any kind of public protest or anything like that.
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

For me personally, I think that one of the biggest factors that influences support for upzoning is the fact that it'll be good for local businesses. And if that's conveyed to the community in a clear and concise manner, it's pretty hard to make a case against it.

Does Affordable Housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I believe it has a huge positive effect. As I said earlier, people need homes to live in. With homes being so unaffordable for most people, having access to more affordable living only increases support for upzoning.

Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Housing affordability absolutely has a positive effect on support for upzoning. As I said earlier, having access to affordable living is the most important thing that one can have. In order to have any kind of access to opportunity, one must be able to have a place to live.

Does Neighborhood character have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think for some people it has a negative impact. Perhaps somebody who's lived in a neighborhood for a long time, many, many years, might be averse to the change, might be averse to the fact that there'll be more people there, services will be more congested. But such is also the nature of progress.

Would small changes in Increased population density lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Small changes in increased population shouldn't have a noticeable effect on support for upzoning. Larger shifts, however, I do believe would have a negative effect.

Would small changes in Transportation services lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Small changes in transportation services shouldn't have much of an effect. Larger changes, however, might start seeing opposition for upzoning. If it comes down to people not having access to the transportation services when they're needed, people are going to naturally be upset about that.

Does Affordable housing needs have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I believe affordable housing needs has a very positive effect on support for upzoning. Many people today are struggling to find affordable housing. People need homes to live in. It's as simple as that.

How would you describe the relationship between Caution in making changes and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the matter has to be handled with caution. The people who are already living in these neighborhoods should have some degree of say when it comes to huge changes like this. It's important to make sure that these people are clearly informed about the positives and the negatives of how upzoning is going to affect their community. A lack of communication will lead to negative feelings over these upzoning changes.

Would small changes in Access to Opportunity lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I believe access to opportunity will have positive effects on support for upzoning. I can't see any reason why they wouldn't.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Housing crisis, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I believe that these upzoning changes will have a positive effect on the housing crisis. More affordable homes for people looking for them will prove the benefits of upzoning. I see no reason why it wouldn't positively affect the crisis.

Is the effect of Resistance to change on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think resistance to the change of support is always going to be immediate. Naturally, it's going to take some time for people to lighten up and see the positives of upzoning. How long that may take depends on how strong of an influence the upzoning benefits are having.

How confident are you that changes in Opposition to Upzoning lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

As more and more people see the positives of upzoning and the good that it brings to the community, you'll start to see more and more support for upzoning. Even the most staunch offenders, or rather, the most rather staunch opposers, can't deny that having more affordable housing is a good thing. That having more affordable house opportunities for people, as well as local businesses benefiting from these changes, they can't deny upzoning is a good thing.

Is the effect of Access to Transportation Services on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The effects of access on transportation services will take some time to develop as more and more people require these services. It's going to start to have a sizable effect on the services themselves. It's important that these transportation services have the ability to accommodate these up-selling changes.

How confident are you that changes in Community involvement lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

As I stated earlier, communicating clearly to the communities affected by upzoning what the positives are and what the negatives are will be the biggest determining factor in whether people support or oppose these changes. A lack of communication will undoubtedly lead to opposition, very strong opposition.

How confident are you that changes in Community involvement lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

qaPairs.answer: Okay.

qaPairs.question: Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
qaPairs.answer: Let's do it.

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: I'd have to say that I am somewhat in favor of it because we're currently experiencing a housing crisis and people need homes.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: The most significant impact would be that there'd be more affordable housing for people who are in need of homes.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: I'd like to think that it would make homes in urban areas more affordable.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer: I think it could be good for the neighborhood and the character of the neighborhood. I think that having more people will make the neighborhood more lively, for instance.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: I think it would actually hurt transportation quite a bit, at least until the services can accommodate the increased number of people.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: I think local government has to make sure that the different services such as transportation services, such as public schools, are going to be able to accommodate the influx of new people in the neighborhood because of the different housing opportunities.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: To be quite honest, I think it would probably be quite bad for the environment. Having more people in a smaller congested area can't be good for the environment, but I think that the need for homes and the need for people to have affordable homes is a little more pressing than the current environmental concerns.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: I think it would be good for local businesses.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: I think making any kind of major change to a place where people have been used to living has to be approached with caution because people generally don't like change and you really have to take that into account when making decisions that people have little to no say in.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: I think one of the biggest issues facing people facing economic issues or equity issues is having access to affordable homes. You can't, or rather, people in general can't not have a home to live in. It's of the utmost importance to have any kind of opportunity in life. The most important thing is to have a place that you can live.

I think that the policies can positively affect support for upzoning if it seems like the rules are fair for everybody involved. Like I said before, having little to no say in the decision ultimately will make people feel uneasy about these kinds of changes. I think that some compromises will have to be made because the last thing you want is any kind of public protest or anything like that.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Upzoning policies and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Upzoning policies â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: For me personally, I think that one of the biggest factors that influences support for upzoning is the fact that it'll be good for local businesses. And if that's conveyed to the community in a clear and concise manner, it's pretty hard to make a case against it.
qaPairs.question: What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: I believe it has a huge positive effect. As I said earlier, people need homes to live in. With homes being so unaffordable for most people, having access to more affordable living only increases support for upzoning.

qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Affordable Housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

But such is also the nature of progress.

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Yes, I'd like you to...

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Hello, hello, hello.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Okay, so let's go ahead and get started.

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
OK, that's wonderful.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay, give me question number one.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

I'm not sure whether I oppose or support but I think that it could bring business in. It does, you know, mess with the contour of the neighborhood. It would have to be voted on by the neighborhood, made sure that it would be safe for the neighborhood, and it brings in money. It is going to be a full decision by the neighborhoods whether or not they're going to want it. And of course neighborhoods are going to be worried about their property values.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

You're going to lose out on the green. There are not going to be as many parks, you know, so people are going to have a lot less space to roam and be out and about. And that is important to neighborhoods, especially if you have children.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

Well, it's entirely possible by the upzoning policies that it could drop the rent in the urban areas in order for it to make it more affordable for people to rent, which is not a bad deal, but what you might bring in in those affordable houses is an element that might bring down the neighborhood.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Well, in a city like New Orleans, you tend to have a lot of hundred, two hundred year old houses. You might not want that sort of modern look of a high rise apartment type building in the midst of these antebellum homes. They're very antique-y and have a certain charm that could be destroyed that would change the characteristic of the neighborhood, yes. But it could bring in new business, new life, new blood that an old neighborhood might need.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

It's entirely possible that the upzoning might create more transport issues, but let's say if you have a five-story building and one of those building slots stories is a parking facility for either the store or for the rooms that would be rented, the apartments, so then that congestion would not necessarily be on the street but contained within the building. That is entirely a possible solution.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

Local government is absolutely part of the regulating the housing development and density, and they would know through discussions, forums, surveys, whether this might be something that the neighborhood might want. I don't see that you might want a 40-story building next to an antebellum home, but maybe having a multi-level building is probably not a bad idea.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

Well for a while you're gonna have a lot of noise from the building of the new house, pouring concrete, taking up space. These are all factors because you don't want to run and build this building while people are trying to sleep. You could also run into sewage issues and water pressure issues in old neighborhoods and that's most of New Orleans.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

Um, having sort of condos in that multifamily housing, um, along next to single-family homes, um, could, could work. You know, you've got, uh, younger people that might want to live in those neighborhoods and couldn't afford a single-family home, or you might have, in this case, um, an elderly person living in the condo that just wants to be part of the neighborhood, it's entirely possible that, you know, this could be good for both.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

Absolutely. In these zoning decisions, you would need to talk to and survey both the future residents and the current residents, especially the current residents, because they're the ones that have been there and may not necessarily want sort of these intruders into the neighborhood.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

Well, those that are moving in with these new high-rise businesses or buildings are going to believe that they should get preferential treatment because they are building these new buildings. And I think that the issue is, of course, those that have been there longer, they should be slightly weighted more, especially if they have children, because you're taking away green space that would have been used for parks or whatever that is encroaching.

How confident are you that changes in Higher density housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I mean, it could lead to a positive effect of bringing, you know, businesses into the neighborhood that may not necessarily have been able to get there before. It could bring opportunities, both positive and negative. It's going to bring, you know, people to their small neighborhood that won't have normally been there. And so, this could be good, but then, you know, these stores could be small community bodegas that are, you know, catering to just this particular neighborhood, which, you know, helps the people in the neighborhood not to have to leave it.
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Some of the factors that support zoning include minimizing urban sprawl and ensuring structured and logical development. Zoning also helps in mitigating conflicts by segregating incompatible land uses. It helps facilitate near residential areas to avoid disturbances from noise and pollution.

Does Parks have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Parks have a positive effect on the neighborhood but a negative effect on upzoning. Upzoning is probably using the park's space to build. And, you know, by getting rid of the park you get rid of the green and the prettiness of the neighborhood. And it makes it feel so clinical, so hospital.

Would small changes in Rent reduction lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Well, historically, zoning practices have employed by affluent communities to boost property values. Zoning also became widespread by leaving out the people that would be of color.

How would you describe the relationship between Historic neighborhood charm and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well it's definitely a weak connection. Historic neighborhood charm would be devastated by modern architecture in the neighborhood. It would absolutely bring down property values and that happened here in New Orleans.

Would small changes in Transportation Systems lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I mean it could positively affect greenhouse gases going down and you know allow people not to use their vehicles to get to work. It's an entirely good thought.

How confident are you that changes in Community input lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that if the community is led by a strong leader, then you might get support for upzoning.

How confident are you that changes in Impact on residents' sleep lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think the upzoning absolutely is going to lead to changes in sleep patterns for residents and that's gonna be a huge negative.

How confident are you that changes in Younger people lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Well, it will help the younger people find places to stay, and that's great, but you're going to end up with more traffic in the neighborhood for established families with kids.

How confident are you that changes in Zoning decisions lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Changes in zoning decisions can lead to support for the up zoning. I just don't think that you're gonna get enough people to make that happen.

How confident are you that changes in Preferential Treatment lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, the preferential treatment leading to what? That people in small independent homes get some sort of tax break because the businesses are there on their land? Well, then that might be a positive effect.

Is the effect of Increased business presence on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Upzoning will never be immediate. It's going to be with the board of the city and you know dealing with the local government takes time.

How would you describe the relationship between Structured and logical development and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I can't give you an answer on structured and logical development, I'm not familiar with it, but with the upzoning, I'm sure that if the development makes sense and doesn't, you know, take away from the neighborhood as a whole, then it might be good.

How would you describe the relationship between Green spaces contribute to neighborhood aesthetics and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
The accumulating evidence of greater availability of green space in the neighborhood associated with health benefits of the local population.
What factors do you think influence Upzoning policies, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

At the end of the day it's going to boil down to whether or not the members of the community are going to want a small upzone building in their neighborhood and then that building has to come with enough compromise in order to make that happen.
What factors do you think influence Upzoning policies, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

You might not want that sort of modern look of a high rise apartment type building in the midst of these antebellum homes. They're very antique-y and have a certain charm that could be destroyed that would change the characteristic of the neighborhood, yes. But it could bring in new business, new life, new blood that an old neighborhood might need.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: It's entirely possible that the upzoning might create more transport issues, but let's say if you have a five-story building and one of those building slots stories is a parking facility for either the store or for the rooms that would be rented, the apartments, so then that congestion would not necessarily be on the street but contained within the building. That is entirely a possible solution.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: Local government is absolutely part of the regulating the housing development and density, and they would know through discussions, forums, surveys, whether this might be something that the neighborhood might want. I don't see that you might want a 40-story building next to an antebellum home, but maybe having a multi-level building is probably not a bad idea.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: Well for a while you're gonna have a lot of noise from the building of the new house, pouring concrete, taking up space. These are all factors because you don't want to run and build this building while people are trying to sleep. You could also run into sewage issues and water pressure issues in old neighborhoods and that's most of New Orleans.

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: Um, having sort of condos in that multifamily housing, um, along next to single-family homes, um, could, could work. You know, you've got, uh, younger people that might want to live in those neighborhoods and couldn't afford a single-family home, or you might have, in this case, um, an elderly person living in the condo that just wants to be part of the neighborhood, it's entirely possible that, you know, this could be good for both.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: Absolutely. In these zoning decisions, you would need to talk to and survey both the future residents and the current residents, especially the current residents, because they're the ones that have been there and may not necessarily want sort of these intruders into the neighborhood.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: Well, those that are moving in with these new high-rise businesses or buildings are going to believe that they should get preferential treatment because they are building these new buildings. And I think that the issue is, of course, those that have been there longer, they should be slightly weighted more, especially if they have children, because you're taking away green space that would have been used for parks or whatever that is encroaching.

I mean, it could lead to a positive effect of bringing, you know, businesses into the neighborhood that may not necessarily have been able to get there before. It could bring opportunities, both positive and negative. It's going to bring, you know, people to their small neighborhood that won't have normally been there. And so, this could be good, but then, you know, these stores could be small community bodegas that are, you know, catering to just this particular neighborhood, which, you know, helps the people in the neighborhood not to have to leave it.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Higher density housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Higher density housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Some of the factors that support zoning include minimizing urban sprawl and ensuring structured and logical development. Zoning also helps in mitigating conflicts by segregating incompatible land uses. It helps facilitate near residential areas to avoid disturbances from noise and pollution.
qaPairs.question: What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: Parks have a positive effect on the neighborhood but a negative effect on upzoning. Upzoning is probably using the park's space to build. And, you know, by getting rid of the park you get rid of the green and the prettiness of the neighborhood. And it makes it feel so clinical, so hospital.
qaPairs.question: Does Parks have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Parks â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, historically, zoning practices have employed by affluent communities to boost property values. Zoning also became widespread by leaving out the people that would be of color.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Rent reduction lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Rent reduction â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well it's definitely a weak connection. Historic neighborhood charm would be devastated by modern architecture in the neighborhood. It would absolutely bring down property values and that happened here in New Orleans.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Historic neighborhood charm and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Historic neighborhood charm â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I mean it could positively affect greenhouse gases going down and you know allow people not to use their vehicles to get to work. It's an entirely good thought.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Transportation Systems lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Transportation Systems â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think that if the community is led by a strong leader, then you might get support for upzoning.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Community input lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Community input â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think the upzoning absolutely is going to lead to changes in sleep patterns for residents and that's gonna be a huge negative.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Impact on residents' sleep lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Impact on residents' sleep â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, it will help the younger people find places to stay, and that's great, but you're going to end up with more traffic in the neighborhood for established families with kids.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Younger people lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Younger people â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Changes in zoning decisions can lead to support for the up zoning. I just don't think that you're gonna get enough people to make that happen.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Zoning decisions lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Zoning decisions â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Well, the preferential treatment leading to what? That people in small independent homes get some sort of tax break because the businesses are there on their land? Well, then that might be a positive effect.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Preferential Treatment lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Preferential Treatment â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Upzoning will never be immediate. It's going to be with the board of the city and you know dealing with the local government takes time.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Increased business presence on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Increased business presence â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I can't give you an answer on structured and logical development, I'm not familiar with it, but with the upzoning, I'm sure that if the development makes sense and doesn't, you know, take away from the neighborhood as a whole, then it might be good.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Structured and logical development and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Structured and logical development â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: The accumulating evidence of greater availability of green space in the neighborhood associated with health benefits of the local population.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Green spaces contribute to neighborhood aesthetics and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Green spaces contribute to neighborhood aesthetics â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: At the end of the day it's going to boil down to whether or not the members of the community are going to want a small upzone building in their neighborhood and then that building has to come with enough compromise in order to make that happen.
qaPairs.question: What factors do you think influence Upzoning policies, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I support it because it would allow more housing to be built and used and hopefully bring the cost of rent down.

It should bring the prices down.

Honestly, comma, I don't really care because when you're homeless and living on the streets, comma, that stuff doesn't matter.

Minimally.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
Local government owes it to their people and their constituents to make sure that there's enough affordable housing and housing options available for everyone to live in their city.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
Environmental concerns don't matter at all until the housing crisis is taken care of and there aren't anymore homeless people.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
I Don't know

Very little, period.

qaPairs.question: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?

I've already tried it, I'm ready.

That's okay. I'm ready to go. Let's start.

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Okay, let's begin
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I like the idea of providing more affordable housing, but I don't like the idea of it creating crowds or blocking sunlight or changing the feel of the surrounding area.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

The most significant impacts are the ones that I already listed. More affordable housing is the positive. The negative is potential crowds, blocking sunlight, or changing the feel of the surrounding area.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
It may lower housing costs, which is good, but I saw in your study that it may only reduce it by 10%, which is not as much as I would like it to be.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
It will feel less peaceful, more chaotic, and more dangerous.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
It might lead to more transportation options in the city, but it also will increase congestion throughout.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
I think they should be responsible for making the decision, but they should use the voice of the public to decide what's right for everybody.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
They might make people more likely to support uphousing, what is it called, upzoning policies, but at the expense of urban density, negative consequences.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
It might make for more jobs in the city, which would benefit the economy in a positive way.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
Current residents should have more of a voice than future residents, in my opinion.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I think they are a contributing factor, but not the deciding factor.

Is the effect of Crowds on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Crowds have a negative, immediate effect in that it lowers the amount of peace and order in the city.
What causes changes in Support for Upzoning? Are these influences strong or weak?
Changes in support for upzoning come from passionate people who feel strongly in what they believe in and these influences are strong and weak on both sides.

Does Blocking Sunlight have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Blocking sunlight has a strong negative effect on support for upzoning, depending on how people are able to design the buildings.

Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Housing affordability has a positive effect on support for upzoning because people need to have access to that, but again, it's not the deciding factor.

Would small changes in Reduction in housing costs lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

If there is a reduction in housing costs, it will, if there's reduction in housing costs without upzoning being implemented, it will not create more support for upzoning. But if the reduction in housing costs is caused by the upzoning policies, then it will have a positive effect.

Would small changes in Chaos lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I would hope that even small changes in chaos would lead to net noticeable changes in support for upzoning, making it less supportable.

How confident are you that changes in Transportation options lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think it's the other way around. I think implementation of upzoning leads to changes in transportation.

Does Decision-making have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Decision-making has a neutral effect on support for upzoning. It all depends on what the decision-making is.

Would small changes in Economic benefit lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Small changes in economic benefit may lead to noticeable changes in support for upzoning, but I believe larger shifts would be more likely to cause changes.

Would small changes in Zoning decisions lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Again, it would depend on what the zoning decision and changes are to know if the support for upzoning would be increased or decreased.

Would small changes in Zoning Policy lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I see this question the same as the last one. It depends on what the zoning policies are to know if the support would be increased or decreased.

Is the effect of Negative effect on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
it takes time to develop. I believe it has a positive effect because overall upzoning may have risks that outweigh the benefits.

How would you describe the relationship between Strong Beliefs and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Strong beliefs do not necessarily correlate to valid support for upzoning if those strong beliefs are based on emotions rather than logic.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Affordable Housing, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
Upzoning may lead to minor decreases in affordable housing or sorry minor increases in affordable housing.

How would you describe the relationship between Noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
This question does not make sense to me.
What causes changes in Blocking Sunlight? Are these influences strong or weak?
Taller buildings such as upzoning implementation has the potential to increase blocked sunlight, and that is a strong influence.
What causes changes in Blocking Sunlight? Are these influences strong or weak?

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
I do feel better about it.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. Okay.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
Okay, I'm ready.
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
I'd say I support it about 75%.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

I would hope that the most important impact would be lowering the cost of living for the housing crisis for individuals, I would say in my area especially, the cost of renting or owning a home has skyrocketed.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

Well, from my understanding, from what I read, upzoning would help lower the cost of rent. I forget what it said, but I'm thinking 10-15%, which is an excellent advantage for those who are desperate for housing.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

There would be problems with traffic, school systems, and the crowding is a worrisome part. Small towns lose that small town feel and become more of a hustle and a bustle. So finding a middle ground for keeping things at a slower pace but allowing for more homes would be the goal.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

Well, transportation would have to be overhauled, traffic signals, roadways, sidewalks, public transportation if it's not there needs to be brought into the city. So these are bringing upzoning in would involve multiple other areas, but it's still vital to be done.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

Well, the local zoning group, the city council members, all of these people would be involved. Things would have to be overhauled. People maybe have to be brought in that haven't been a part of it before so that all the statistics and issues can be figured out. For example, currently in my city, we have an overcrowding. For some reason, the city has been allowing more and more and more and more apartments to come in, but none of these are affordable apartments. These are high-end apartments, and the lower-income families are becoming homeless.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

I suppose environmental factors like sewage, making sure the water and sewage is dealt with is highly important because without the abilities to deal with that, that could cause major issues. So that environmentally is important for that, electricity, enough power, enough electricity, enough fuel for fueling cars. And then the, you know, the byproduct of all of that, including refuge, trash.
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

Well, both positive and negative results would be positive for the changing the laws would be allowing for lower cost of living, lower rent, lower, more affordability. That would be an excellent, positive, very important aspect about bringing up, you know, allowing the changes for zoning to be made. And then you have the negative, which is the cost of changing and making sure roads, trash, utilities, schools, all of these things have to be addressed, which take time and money.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

I think current residents should have a say. I really do, especially in the smaller communities. Now on the outskirts of town where there's more property, more availability to put in some taller buildings that wouldn't obstruct some of these housing districts, would be a better option. So I think involving the community in each separate housing district, getting the views of the people, and making sure that there's a middle ground for everybody.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
I don't think they play a role.
What factors do you think influence Support for Upzoning, and how strong is their impact? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).
I'd say the biggest influence for supporting upzoning is housing affordability is number one.

Is the effect of Lowering the cost of living on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It has a positive effect. Bringing in more people that can afford to live, all these people will be paying for utilities, paying for sewage, paying for their trash and refuge, paying to shop for their necessities. So this brings in multiple aspects of influencing and bringing money back into the community.

How would you describe the relationship between Reduction in rent costs and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It has a strong connection because it it will bring in funds for we're talking middle class affordability, middle lower class affordability of homes is a is a support of upzoning because it's strong connection because it brings money back into the community. Taxing brings money back into the government for structures, street care, utility care to up build it all.

Would small changes in Transportation overhaul lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Yes, I believe small changes in transportation would make a big difference. It could bring in people that choose to use public transportation rather than overcrowding with different cars and such in apartment, especially in upzoning a lot of people would rather walk, drive, or use public transportation.

How would you describe the relationship between Overhaul of Current Systems and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I say changes in transportation and the relationship between overhauling the current system and supporting for the upzoning system is a positive thing. I think it would bring in multi-million dollars to the community, to the shopping, to the small businesses, to the utilities, to the sewer, to the local government. It's a positive aspect.

Does Affordable Housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
It has a positive aspect, it has a positive influence upon it. The effect is increasing the homes to bring in the money to bring the people to support the community.

How would you describe the relationship between sewage management and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It's a big connection, the connection between sewage and upzoning. Upzoning and sewage will definitely have to collaborate and make sure that the infrastructure is there, and if it's not, it will require building and providing the sewage and the water capabilities. And then from that, the money would be brought back in because the people would be paying for the sewage and utilities that that all involves.

Would small changes in Affordability lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think the small changes in affordability will lead to noticeable changes in support. If people are actually able to see that, say we start with one building, and it doesn't cause the issues that people are concerned about. That the issues of the overcrowding have been dealt with. The roads, the lights, the sidewalks, the trash, the utilities. All of it's dealt with, and the building, the people that are brought in, actually contribute to the community and not cause a problem. So if the attributes that need to be dealt with before the building comes in, and they see that the community is actually flourishing, then more buildings can come in, but at a limit.

How confident are you that changes in Community involvement lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Yes, it has a powerful effect. The community, the trust, I believe the trust is what makes it a positive.

Does Housing affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

This is kind of a repetitive question you're asking, but yes, I believe that housing affordability has a positive effect in supporting upzoning, and I believe it's a significant effect. If the housing affordability in this, my local area, was reduced by 10%, it would make a huge impact on support of the community and the people that surround the community and live in the community that are struggling to find and afford their homes.

Would small changes in Positive Effect lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Yes, because a strong effect would occur with the trust of the people and the money that's brought in would influence the small businesses.

Would small changes in Economic Contributions lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Yes, I believe the economic contributions would lead to a strong noticeable change, a big impact in the support of upzoning.

Does Middle class affordability have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Middle class affordability has a positive effect. Middle class, when you say middle class, most likely you're speaking about the majority. Majority of the middle class, the people, will make a positive impact if they're for it.

Is the effect of Public transportation usage on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Absolutely, public transportation and the availability of it would be a huge support for upzoning because one, it brings in business and two, it will help with crowding of cars if you're talking about a building and where the cars would be kept, parking area and so forth. Absolutely, yes, large impact.

How confident are you that changes in Utilities lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Well, I don't know for sure if the changes in utility would lead to support of the upzoning. What I do know is if the changes in the utilities are addressed before and put into effect of more housing coming in when they're dealt with not just one building but in the future if you're looking in and building for the future the utilities will be a plus. It will be in support of upzoning because you're saying hey we're prepared if this is something that our community wants to do we are ready and prepared. You can trust in our government. You can trust that we're doing the right thing.
What causes changes in Lowering the cost of living? Are these influences strong or weak?

Yes, lowering the cost of living is an absolute plus, especially when there are people homeless living on the street, or lower middle class people that should be able to afford a home are not able to afford a home, and living with family, living in tents, and living in hotels. Yes, it's a positive, strong positive effect.

Does Economic Impact have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

The economy has a huge effect bringing in the upzoning in support of the upzoning because you're bringing in Like from what I read the upzoning you would have the first floor would be small shops that people could support small Businesses and it brings money to the community It brings the small businesses the people they shop they bring money. They need necessities This requires money which the community of the upzoning from the people living in the homes Can give to the community it is a strong positive

negative- no one wants their road to be congested. no one wants people speeding by their homes

it could be an economic boost- more money for business, more taxes from residents,etc

I think it would decrease it fairly strongly

I thikn there are positives for some, and what is a positive for some is a negative for others. It's a double edged sword. There are two sides with very different views.

Does Business revenue have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Yes business revenue is positive.

is this all?

I think the effect is moderate.  It decreases it.
