messages.text: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
Bye.

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Okay. Yes.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Yes

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
Yes.

As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
Okay.
Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
I'm ready
To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.

That really depends on the target demographics for the properties themselves. I mean, are they going to be, you know, Section 8 or is it going to be, you know, fancy looking glass towers or something? If it's the first one, I do not, because usually when that type of housing comes in, and I understand, you know, not everybody's fortunate as others, but that tends to just degrade neighborhoods. There's no real nice way to put it, but it just does. And I, you know, it's not just a, you know, there's no bias against any certain people or anything. It's just, you know, facts are facts. If you look at pretty much any neighborhood that's ever brought Section 8 to it, it declines. So, in general, for that, no, but if it's, you know, an upscale building, middle class people, families, that kind of thing, I'm okay with that.
What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?

The biggest positive impacts are, for affordable housing, people can have a place to live. But the negative is, while that's a step up for some people, it's a step back for others, especially if it's an affluent neighborhood, then to them it's an eyesore. Now here's the thing, I'm actually, I would be more in favor of Section 8 housing as long as it affected everybody. If I'm in a middle class neighborhood and I get it, then there's no reason that somebody along Central Park South at West 59th Street shouldn't have the same exact building codes and standards that everybody else has. But other than that, it gets really crowded. I mean parking where I'm at is a non-starter anyway because there's never any, but it does increase that. There are, you could say there's more foot traffic for businesses, but I mean a lot of times then that foot traffic isn't bad or isn't good for the good kind of foot traffic. What if it's a bunch of vagrants that move in there living off the system and they're drug dealers, they come in and they rob the places or they graffiti shop windows. It's not good. So overall, again, this comes down to the target, who the homes are being built for. If it's for middle class families and that kind of thing, that can be extra positive because then the foot traffic does, they go into stores and they patronize businesses and they pay for the goods. They don't steal them or vandalize things. But it can be quite the extreme in either direction.
How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?

Affordability should, in theory, at least, go up, making prices go down. However, here's the thing, it's only a matter of time before people get pushed out, or some greedy politician or landlord wants to come in there and start tweaking things, it doesn't take long for greed, or there could be, it could actually be detrimental to a neighborhood if the tax base gets sick of all the crime and the filth and decides to move. The people to get out first are the ones that make out, because the people to get out last, they're usually underwater in their real estate values and there's nothing left. But in theory, it should work, but in the long run, it almost always, always, always does the opposite, because somebody comes in, some developer comes in and wants to turn it into some glass tower, it's only a matter of time before that happens, especially if the crime rate goes way up because of the housing, it's only a matter of time before the neighborhood either fights back and has it renovated into something better suited, or they move and the neighborhood collapses. In the short term, it does. I think it does lower the prices and increase affordability, but in the long term, it doesn't.
What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?

Um, it depends on the demographic if the people that move in there are middle class or above and they have, you know, good paying jobs, then, you know, it can bring prosperity. The businesses thrive, the general vibe of the neighborhood is always better too. People are just in a better mood. But at the same time, you know, it's going to increase foot traffic. It's going to increase the amount of cars and trucks on the road. Another thing, it can clog sidewalks. It can also increase loads on things like, uh, utilities, water, sewer, sewer is a big thing. You know, imagine you go to flush your toilet and the system's taxed because they've got 5,000 new apartments it's pulling off of and now it takes two times to flush your toilet. That alone can, you know, once or twice, maybe not a big deal, but that happens every day. Especially in a house that you're paying for that didn't have that problem before your new neighbors moved in and, you know, are they going to pay for it? Yeah, no, they're there because they can't afford things as it is and that, you know, I'm not trying to punish them for that, but this is, you know, I'm just trying to be real. So, um, but the, you know, it, it can also affect the job market too. Um, if the, um, if there's not enough of an economy to support that many inhabitants, you know, um, that, that can too. So, um, hospitals, that's another thing. School systems, uh, quality of education goes down. The classrooms get packed and the teacher can't dedicate time to students. Yeah, it's, um, it can have a major impact, but, uh, you know, again, if this is focused on section eight, I, I lean, I'm in the camp that it's going to have a negative quality of life effect, but if it's middle-class, um, or above, I think it, uh, it would be, uh, it would have a positive impact.
How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?

It, it's definitely gonna impact those, um, you know, in certain cities, it, the impact might not even be that felt because if it's, you know, rush hour, it's a mad house. In a city, let's just say you're in a city of like 8 million people, uh, you know, an extra 30,000 people in the grand scheme of things, you know, even if it's a, a building that's got, I don't know, a hundred thousand people, I mean, yeah, that's an increase, but depending on, uh, the, the areas you're at and, um, they're scheduled to, you know, if they're, uh, frontline workers and they go to work before everybody else, then it might not, you know, you might not even notice it at all, but, um, yeah, that, that can affect it too. Plus the city's gonna want to probably raise prices on public transportation cause it's gonna mean more demand, um, which is ironic because most of them aren't going to pay for it and it's gonna, uh, break the system even more. But, um, yeah, there, there will, you know, um, if, if it's Section 8 housing, traffic congestion might not be as bad as transportation systems. The opposite's true if it's a middle class or above, those people can afford cars, uh, they would put, you know, that would be more traffic. So, um, yeah, I, I think the biggest thing will be the increased maintenance and capacity needs as well as price hikes.
What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?

I think they need to focus on middle-class housing for everybody. Don't allow these big glass skyscrapers that cost millions of dollars, you know, for 400 square feet, and don't, you know, run places into the ground. Don't set up, you know, make every neighborhood a ghetto. If everybody had a nice single family home, you know, that's part of it. You know, people have pride of where they live at. If they live in just some concrete building that's got, you know, looks like it's more suited for a warehouse than people living in it, then that's a problem. But I think the density should be equivalent to the jobs, the infrastructure, the school system, and the medical system. You know, if it's affecting that to where, you know, people can't get doctor's appointments and, you know, buses are running behind and that kind of thing, then I don't think they should allow that much density. But the local government should definitely regulate who the developers are, too, that get these contracts. You know, it seems like there's no wonder the rich keep getting richer. And it's ironic that it's programs like these that allow them to do it because they go out and they'll get, you know, whoever, whatever construction company donated money to them, or they're connected to a certain lobby. Or another thing, too, is in the construction industry, there's a lot of those business owners are racist, you know, and they, but then they benefit when projects like this come up. And it's kind of feeding, it keeps feeding that, it's a vicious cycle. That's part of the reason that racism is still so strong. So they should have, make business owners or contractors take lie detector tests, you know, before they're issued any government contracts. Because it's silly to claim to be some moral superior nation, but when the rubber hits the road, you know, we don't care who we make rich, you know, if it's some racist construction company with their family name on the door, and they just happen to do the job cheaper, you know, and the government gives them money, that's wrong. So they should play a role in vetting who they give contracts to as well for these developments.
How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?

Um There was there definitely be an increase in carbon emissions and greenhouse gases Depending on if the people drove cars or not Would be the deciding factor on how much the increase is Even if they didn't drive a car at all walked everywhere There's still wear and tear going on which causes, you know, there's erosion And That kind of thing that that takes place and the more people That use it the quicker The quicker things deteriorate so But also, you know if it's in a somewhat suburban area where there's still some Some nature left then, you know, you could be destroying Part of the ecosystem You know and It's not hard to To To upset the balance of nature Just by adding a few houses in the right or wrong location depending how you how you look at it, but You know Just an extra 5,000 cars, you know, if there's a building that brings 10,000 people you can pretty much count at least one of one out of two of them is going to have a car So and That definitely affects air quality which affects people's physical and mental health There's been studies showing that that's linked to all kinds of health issues so Health issues, so that's also something something to consider
What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?

I think in the short run, there will be more affordable housing, which is good and bad because nobody wants to see people homeless. At the same time, if you get the wrong type of people that move into an otherwise nice neighborhood, it can be devastating. Once your tax base moves out, for whatever reason, it's usually over. That's when businesses shutter, abandoned lots, vacant houses, and the next step from that is a dilapidated neighborhood, which nobody wants. On the flip side, if it's a middle-class neighborhood that's put in place, they can boost an economy. If they're spending money, their businesses will thrive to an extent, certain ones anyway. That can be another negative, too, because then you're talking about more traffic, more congestion, higher infrastructure costs, which usually means you're going to need to ask for more taxes. In the long run, what usually happens is they push out the people that were put in the affordable housing, and they either knock the building down or they renovate it into a bushified millionaire's tower, which is ironic because there goes all your affordable housing.
How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?

For the most part, I think majority rules. If the majority of the tax base says they don't want it, then I guess the majority should rule in that case. I suppose there's an argument to be made, federal tax dollars could be a bigger picture. But I think if it's going to bring in a better tax base, that should be something too. If it's just going to be people that are broke because they don't want to work and they sell drugs, then the residents have a legitimate concern and the local government should side with the people in that case. But at the same time, if the residents can't come up with anything other than infrastructure or carbon release, then I don't think their argument is strong. In general, I think the majority should rule.
What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?

This is kind of tricky. I think everybody deserves an equal shot at the American dream. However, I don't think people should be allowed to bring other people down. So, you know, if someone's homeless and they move into a Section 8 housing, that's a huge step up for them. But if you build a Section 8 complex in an affluent or even a middle class neighborhood, that brings other people down. And, you know, that's just how it is. And I think that if any developer that tears down affordable housing should have to build an equal number of new units to replace the old ones for the people that they kick out. But that said, I think certain people deserve to be closer to the front of the line for programs like this than others. Some of them, they make their living off of this. That's not right. So, you know, somebody that, if they're like a college student working two jobs and they need affordable housing, that's the kind of person we want. We don't want the person who, you know, got five kids with five different baby daddies, okay? No, that's not right. So, yeah, I think there should be some type of hierarchy for priorities when dealing with social equity and the access.

Does Higher density housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I Think higher density Has a It I think it's actually it's both You know when when there gets to be so many people Crammed into Small spaces they need You know you need more units But It can also have a negative effect If people get inconvenient especially by people that they see as Leeches people that just you know They're a piece of crap And you know not that just because report but because they choose to stay like that they don't do anything to To pick themselves up so And that has a negative effect on general opinion because when people see someone see a Program get taken advantage like that You know the their instant reaction is to say well, let's just cut it and that's not fair because there are people that that Legitimately need those programs and should be able to to access them so But I do think it it's more negative because it taxes the system overall From start to finish. I mean you're talking about Permits and construction areas and Dirt and debris for months or years, you know and jackhammers going people don't want to live like that, so Yeah, I think overall it has a negative effect
What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I Think if there was a level playing field for everybody again. I mentioned this earlier if Everybody's house was just basically the same I mean at least you I don't know you could have different designs and that kind of thing but square footage You know the size of the house and that kind of if everybody was on a level playing field. I think more people would Would be on board with it they would know that there's a what to expect they could you know plan for things You know somebody that lives in a single-family neighborhood with detached homes You know and all of a sudden some Tall building comes in and blocks their view to the I don't know some landscape or river or whatever you know That that'll decrease support However if You know if you want to To equalize things I think more people Would be able to get behind something like that But You know rich people don't want to move into a neighborhood where they don't know in five years There's going to be a ghetto next door and You know same thing with people that are less fortunate They don't want to move in the low-income neighborhood only to have some Bouchifide tower go in there raising property taxes cost living you know Their rents go up, and then next thing you know Some greedy developer wants to come in knock down their building and put up a new one So I Think if there was if everybody lived in like had a an equal playing field That would increase The support for upzoning

How confident are you that changes in Section 8 housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I'm pretty confident that Section 8 housing leads to changes for upzoning, and depending where you live at, it'll be good or bad. I think people either love it or hate it. There's no in between. If it's a good neighborhood and they're bringing in Section 8, then it's going to be, they're going to lose support. If it's an industrial area or one that's already low income, it may have a short-term positive effect because people will be able to have a place they can afford. But it would be pretty strong either way.

How confident are you that changes in Middle-class families lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I'm very confident that middle class families would increase support for upzoning. It's true they would increase some traffic, congestion, that kind of thing, but they would have the money to be able to afford to upgrade things like infrastructure, utilities, school systems, first responders, hospitals, that could accommodate the influx of people. And overall, I think that would be a very positive effect because when you have strong middle class neighborhoods that can afford to go out to eat and take a vacation, go to the movies, everybody benefits from that and the effect from that is pretty strong.

Is the effect of Positive vs Negative Impacts on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

It depends if there's going to be something the community is going to benefit from. If the developer offers to put in new roads, expand the school, and upgrade the sewer system in return for the new zoning, it could be a positive effect that's felt pretty quick. I mean, people would, even though it wouldn't be in place, they could see it on the horizon. They would know that it's coming. At the same time, let's say they do that, but when they do that, they have to install a bigger pump because there's more taxing of the sewer system, and that takes more energy to run, which in turn raises utility costs. That's something that wouldn't be felt until longer term, but overall, I think people pretty much have their minds made up. When you say upzoning, they automatically know what that means, and they have their feelings already set. For somebody that's totally dead set against it, I don't know that you could ... Well, you might be able to pay them to change their mind, but short of that, I don't see them giving an inch. People on the other side of it, same thing. They want the housing really bad. This might be their only shot at ever getting a roof over their head, so they're going to fight like hell for it, too. I think most of the effects are ... Most of the negative effects, I think, are felt, actually felt later on after things are in place, but people have their minds made up before they go into things like that.

Would small changes in Housing Affordability lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think it would add some support in some areas for upzoning, but I think a larger shift is what it would take to really move the needle. You're going to have to make everybody confident that they're not going to be upsold or downsold either way. That's understandable. I'd say let's do affordable housing, but it has to be comparable to what's in the neighborhood. It can't stick out like a sore thumb. If there's nice single-family detached with well-kept lawns, don't be putting up some under-blocked building that looks like an eyesore, because no matter how much affordability that is, people are going to hate it, except for the inhabitants. I think a shift in evening out the properties themselves among the population would have a strong positive effect and support.

How would you describe the relationship between Short-term Benefits and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Yeah, it's a good relationship for short term. People get the housing they want for the prices they can afford, but that's not usually how the entire surrounding community feels about it. But in the beginning, there's a strong connection because people, you know, they just got a roof over their head. But in the long run, I just have a feeling that if it's, you know, not a middle class or above standard, then it's a very strong negative effect. And it's felt through the entire community because people, you know, they had, were living, their lives were fine before this happened. So that would be a very strong effect. I can tell you myself that would, you'd get a strong reaction from me if that happened.

How would you describe the relationship between Prosperity and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

There is actually a strong support for upzoning. The relationship between prosperity and support for it is actually closer than what you might think, but only because the rich people usually think in long term. They see a new Section 8 building go up in a prime neighborhood, they're thinking five years down the road how they're going to be able to kick the people out, knock down the basketball courts and put up a new tower. So it's ironic in that sense, but immediately there's a disconnect, especially if it's a nice neighborhood. People just know what that's going to do to their values, to their lives in general is going to change. That's not what they signed up for in the beginning, and they have a right to be mad. So yeah, I think if you're rich and you can hold out until a rich developer comes in and increases everybody's property value by putting up a new tower, I think it's a more negative effect depending what social class you're from.

Would small changes in City Population Size lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Uh, small changes and it, it can, I think in certain areas, uh, depending what side of the political spectrum those people are on, you know, if they're liberal, uh, they, you could have a, an entire neighborhood that's all for, um, affordable housing. And again, if you're in a more conservative neighborhood, um, you know, that's, uh, or, or just one where there's high net worth individuals, yeah, they're, they're going to fight you every step of the way. Um, but it can, you know, especially if, um, in a state like Florida where it could be seasonal during the, the summer, Florida's liberal population swells or in the winter, and then in the summer it goes down. So, um, and in that case it, it could, it, you know, that it could be like the tide going in and out, um, that would be an interesting, uh, uh, interesting study to figure that out. But, uh, I think overall, um, small changes in population size wouldn't have that big of an effect.

Would small changes in Neighborhood quality lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Yeah, I don't think it would take much for small changes to upset somebody's way of life. And when that happens, it's almost always negative. I can't see how somebody would, I don't know, to me I think of something like going to the grocery store and instead of always having an empty lane to check out in right away, now all the lanes have five or six people in, you know. You go to a restaurant or something and now there's a waiting line, you know, or not. That could be a change too, but if people, you know, if they start ripping out like, I don't know, a nice park and they start putting up basketball courts, people don't want to see that. That would be something that would probably be enough to make a lot of people not support upzoning or a baseball field. That's another thing, which wouldn't necessarily be a big change to me, you know, that would be a small change, but it would make a big difference. So I think that would have a, I think small changes do have a strong effect.

How would you describe the relationship between greenhouse gases and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think that depends on what part of the country you live in you can if you're in New York City You're gonna get a lot of pushback if you don't have green written all over Your project whereas, you know some place that's maybe Republican like Texas or something they don't care what you do, you know, if you you tell them you're putting up a building and you're gonna make a business out of it and bring tax dollars or bring jobs, they'll let you do anything. So I think it's a strong effect either way, but it depends on depends on the area

Does Gentrification have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

That depends on the community itself. If it's Section 8 going into a neighborhood that's already filled with Section 8, I don't know that that's going to cause a strong effect, but gentrification alone, yes, has a very strong effect, and it's on both sides. The people moving into a neighborhood, they see it as they're getting a deal. You move somebody, well, take New York. An apartment in Midtown or SoHo is going to cost you five, six grand for a studio. You move uptown above 99th or something, and prices come down, but you're still in the city, and you're okay with that. However, you're saving money, but by you moving there, you actually pushed out someone that was paying less money. Now, to the people in that neighborhood, you're the reason their rents are going up, not down. It's a very strong effect. For the people that are part of the gentrification, it's positive. For the people that are not part of the gentrification, the lower income, it's a negative.

Would small changes in Tax Base lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think an increase in tax base would lead to more support for upzoning if they were moving in middle class people or above. However, the opposite is true if it's low income. I think that's a strong negative effect because middle class and above people can afford to pay more taxes to upgrade the things needed to accommodate the rise in population. People that move into section 8 cannot. Hello Jason, this is Vicki with Zingo. I was calling about your appointment with us on Wednesday, May 21st for the study on opinions on health. That study has been changed. The time of it has. It's now going to start at 3.30 p.m. Eastern Time and it'll be for one hour. Are you available from 3.30 till 4.30? Yup, that's the same day, right? Yes, same day. Just the time. Okay, 5.21 at 3.30 for an hour. Yes. Okay, I got it. Thank you so much. I'm going to send you a confirmation email. Okay, that would be great. That'll have the new link to it, right? Yes. No, you'll be getting the link and another email from Qual Meeting. Oh, okay. I gotcha. I understand. Thank you. Bye-bye. Thank you. Bye.

How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
I think that would be a negative effect in support for that. Congestion means people have longer commute times to and from work and that is a big no-no so that would be a strong negative effect.

Does Homelessness have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

Homelessness has a strong negative effect for upzoning. That is probably one of the most, that's probably one of the biggest concerns people have on upzoning is especially if it's going to be a section 8 building, people worry that there's going to be homeless camps set up. And they don't, you know, that is a definite no-no, especially if it's a neighborhood with lots of families. People are scared for their kids and their quality of life. It's just not, just not good.

How would you describe the relationship between Social Equity and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?

I think social equity and support for upzoning, there's definitely a strong connection there, you know, because we're not being honest if we think there's not a huge divide between the haves and the have-nots in society. And I think that's the general theory behind affordable housing and upzoning, but sometimes I think they only see that, you know, they don't see the things that the negative consequences, you know, like increased congestion, tax, utilities like that, you know, schools, hospitals, that kind of thing. But then they, it's like they just, once the neighborhood's been demolished, they just, they look for another place to try again. And I think that has an increasingly negative effect. But for right now, I think social equity and support for upzoning share a close relationship.

How would you describe the relationship between Replacement of Affordable Housing and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
Thank you.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

I think an equal playing field among the structures themselves is key to gaining support. The physical appearance and size of the properties much match the size and decor of the surroundings. By doing this people don't have to worry about being upsold or down sold.
What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.question: Welcome to the Trace Your Thinking interview system. This platform is designed to capture your thoughts about urban zoning and housing development. Would you like me to guide you through using this system?
qaPairs.answer: Bye.

qaPairs.question: You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
qaPairs.answer: Okay. Yes.

qaPairs.question: For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
qaPairs.answer: Yes

qaPairs.question: You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
qaPairs.answer: Yes.

qaPairs.question: As the interview progresses, you'll notice the progress bar at the top of the screen showing your current position. Based on your responses, the system may generate follow-up questions to dive deeper into specific topics. These new questions will be added to your interview flow automatically. This helps us capture your thinking process more thoroughly.
qaPairs.answer: Okay.

qaPairs.question: Excellent! We're now ready to begin the interview about urban zoning policies. Take your time with each response and provide as much detail as you'd like. Let's start with our first question.
qaPairs.answer: I'm ready

qaPairs.question: To what extent do you support or oppose upzoning policies that allow for higher density housing in traditionally single-family neighborhoods? Please explain your reasoning.
qaPairs.answer: That really depends on the target demographics for the properties themselves. I mean, are they going to be, you know, Section 8 or is it going to be, you know, fancy looking glass towers or something? If it's the first one, I do not, because usually when that type of housing comes in, and I understand, you know, not everybody's fortunate as others, but that tends to just degrade neighborhoods. There's no real nice way to put it, but it just does. And I, you know, it's not just a, you know, there's no bias against any certain people or anything. It's just, you know, facts are facts. If you look at pretty much any neighborhood that's ever brought Section 8 to it, it declines. So, in general, for that, no, but if it's, you know, an upscale building, middle class people, families, that kind of thing, I'm okay with that.

qaPairs.question: What do you think are the most significant impacts, positive or negative, of increasing housing density in residential neighborhoods?
qaPairs.answer: The biggest positive impacts are, for affordable housing, people can have a place to live. But the negative is, while that's a step up for some people, it's a step back for others, especially if it's an affluent neighborhood, then to them it's an eyesore. Now here's the thing, I'm actually, I would be more in favor of Section 8 housing as long as it affected everybody. If I'm in a middle class neighborhood and I get it, then there's no reason that somebody along Central Park South at West 59th Street shouldn't have the same exact building codes and standards that everybody else has. But other than that, it gets really crowded. I mean parking where I'm at is a non-starter anyway because there's never any, but it does increase that. There are, you could say there's more foot traffic for businesses, but I mean a lot of times then that foot traffic isn't bad or isn't good for the good kind of foot traffic. What if it's a bunch of vagrants that move in there living off the system and they're drug dealers, they come in and they rob the places or they graffiti shop windows. It's not good. So overall, again, this comes down to the target, who the homes are being built for. If it's for middle class families and that kind of thing, that can be extra positive because then the foot traffic does, they go into stores and they patronize businesses and they pay for the goods. They don't steal them or vandalize things. But it can be quite the extreme in either direction.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning policies might affect housing affordability in urban areas?
qaPairs.answer: Affordability should, in theory, at least, go up, making prices go down. However, here's the thing, it's only a matter of time before people get pushed out, or some greedy politician or landlord wants to come in there and start tweaking things, it doesn't take long for greed, or there could be, it could actually be detrimental to a neighborhood if the tax base gets sick of all the crime and the filth and decides to move. The people to get out first are the ones that make out, because the people to get out last, they're usually underwater in their real estate values and there's nothing left. But in theory, it should work, but in the long run, it almost always, always, always does the opposite, because somebody comes in, some developer comes in and wants to turn it into some glass tower, it's only a matter of time before that happens, especially if the crime rate goes way up because of the housing, it's only a matter of time before the neighborhood either fights back and has it renovated into something better suited, or they move and the neighborhood collapses. In the short term, it does. I think it does lower the prices and increase affordability, but in the long term, it doesn't.

qaPairs.question: What impact do you believe increased housing density might have on neighborhood character and quality of life?
qaPairs.answer: Um, it depends on the demographic if the people that move in there are middle class or above and they have, you know, good paying jobs, then, you know, it can bring prosperity. The businesses thrive, the general vibe of the neighborhood is always better too. People are just in a better mood. But at the same time, you know, it's going to increase foot traffic. It's going to increase the amount of cars and trucks on the road. Another thing, it can clog sidewalks. It can also increase loads on things like, uh, utilities, water, sewer, sewer is a big thing. You know, imagine you go to flush your toilet and the system's taxed because they've got 5,000 new apartments it's pulling off of and now it takes two times to flush your toilet. That alone can, you know, once or twice, maybe not a big deal, but that happens every day. Especially in a house that you're paying for that didn't have that problem before your new neighbors moved in and, you know, are they going to pay for it? Yeah, no, they're there because they can't afford things as it is and that, you know, I'm not trying to punish them for that, but this is, you know, I'm just trying to be real. So, um, but the, you know, it, it can also affect the job market too. Um, if the, um, if there's not enough of an economy to support that many inhabitants, you know, um, that, that can too. So, um, hospitals, that's another thing. School systems, uh, quality of education goes down. The classrooms get packed and the teacher can't dedicate time to students. Yeah, it's, um, it can have a major impact, but, uh, you know, again, if this is focused on section eight, I, I lean, I'm in the camp that it's going to have a negative quality of life effect, but if it's middle-class, um, or above, I think it, uh, it would be, uh, it would have a positive impact.

qaPairs.question: How do you think upzoning might affect transportation systems and traffic congestion in cities?
qaPairs.answer: It, it's definitely gonna impact those, um, you know, in certain cities, it, the impact might not even be that felt because if it's, you know, rush hour, it's a mad house. In a city, let's just say you're in a city of like 8 million people, uh, you know, an extra 30,000 people in the grand scheme of things, you know, even if it's a, a building that's got, I don't know, a hundred thousand people, I mean, yeah, that's an increase, but depending on, uh, the, the areas you're at and, um, they're scheduled to, you know, if they're, uh, frontline workers and they go to work before everybody else, then it might not, you know, you might not even notice it at all, but, um, yeah, that, that can affect it too. Plus the city's gonna want to probably raise prices on public transportation cause it's gonna mean more demand, um, which is ironic because most of them aren't going to pay for it and it's gonna, uh, break the system even more. But, um, yeah, there, there will, you know, um, if, if it's Section 8 housing, traffic congestion might not be as bad as transportation systems. The opposite's true if it's a middle class or above, those people can afford cars, uh, they would put, you know, that would be more traffic. So, um, yeah, I, I think the biggest thing will be the increased maintenance and capacity needs as well as price hikes.

qaPairs.question: What role do you believe local government should play in regulating housing development and density?
qaPairs.answer: I think they need to focus on middle-class housing for everybody. Don't allow these big glass skyscrapers that cost millions of dollars, you know, for 400 square feet, and don't, you know, run places into the ground. Don't set up, you know, make every neighborhood a ghetto. If everybody had a nice single family home, you know, that's part of it. You know, people have pride of where they live at. If they live in just some concrete building that's got, you know, looks like it's more suited for a warehouse than people living in it, then that's a problem. But I think the density should be equivalent to the jobs, the infrastructure, the school system, and the medical system. You know, if it's affecting that to where, you know, people can't get doctor's appointments and, you know, buses are running behind and that kind of thing, then I don't think they should allow that much density. But the local government should definitely regulate who the developers are, too, that get these contracts. You know, it seems like there's no wonder the rich keep getting richer. And it's ironic that it's programs like these that allow them to do it because they go out and they'll get, you know, whoever, whatever construction company donated money to them, or they're connected to a certain lobby. Or another thing, too, is in the construction industry, there's a lot of those business owners are racist, you know, and they, but then they benefit when projects like this come up. And it's kind of feeding, it keeps feeding that, it's a vicious cycle. That's part of the reason that racism is still so strong. So they should have, make business owners or contractors take lie detector tests, you know, before they're issued any government contracts. Because it's silly to claim to be some moral superior nation, but when the rubber hits the road, you know, we don't care who we make rich, you know, if it's some racist construction company with their family name on the door, and they just happen to do the job cheaper, you know, and the government gives them money, that's wrong. So they should play a role in vetting who they give contracts to as well for these developments.

qaPairs.question: How might environmental concerns factor into decisions about urban density and zoning?
qaPairs.answer: Um There was there definitely be an increase in carbon emissions and greenhouse gases Depending on if the people drove cars or not Would be the deciding factor on how much the increase is Even if they didn't drive a car at all walked everywhere There's still wear and tear going on which causes, you know, there's erosion And That kind of thing that that takes place and the more people That use it the quicker The quicker things deteriorate so But also, you know if it's in a somewhat suburban area where there's still some Some nature left then, you know, you could be destroying Part of the ecosystem You know and It's not hard to To To upset the balance of nature Just by adding a few houses in the right or wrong location depending how you how you look at it, but You know Just an extra 5,000 cars, you know, if there's a building that brings 10,000 people you can pretty much count at least one of one out of two of them is going to have a car So and That definitely affects air quality which affects people's physical and mental health There's been studies showing that that's linked to all kinds of health issues so Health issues, so that's also something something to consider

qaPairs.question: What economic effects, both positive and negative, might result from changing zoning laws to allow more multi-family housing?
qaPairs.answer: I think in the short run, there will be more affordable housing, which is good and bad because nobody wants to see people homeless. At the same time, if you get the wrong type of people that move into an otherwise nice neighborhood, it can be devastating. Once your tax base moves out, for whatever reason, it's usually over. That's when businesses shutter, abandoned lots, vacant houses, and the next step from that is a dilapidated neighborhood, which nobody wants. On the flip side, if it's a middle-class neighborhood that's put in place, they can boost an economy. If they're spending money, their businesses will thrive to an extent, certain ones anyway. That can be another negative, too, because then you're talking about more traffic, more congestion, higher infrastructure costs, which usually means you're going to need to ask for more taxes. In the long run, what usually happens is they push out the people that were put in the affordable housing, and they either knock the building down or they renovate it into a bushified millionaire's tower, which is ironic because there goes all your affordable housing.

qaPairs.question: How do you think the interests of current residents versus future residents should be balanced when making zoning decisions?
qaPairs.answer: For the most part, I think majority rules. If the majority of the tax base says they don't want it, then I guess the majority should rule in that case. I suppose there's an argument to be made, federal tax dollars could be a bigger picture. But I think if it's going to bring in a better tax base, that should be something too. If it's just going to be people that are broke because they don't want to work and they sell drugs, then the residents have a legitimate concern and the local government should side with the people in that case. But at the same time, if the residents can't come up with anything other than infrastructure or carbon release, then I don't think their argument is strong. In general, I think the majority should rule.

qaPairs.question: What role do you think social equity and access to opportunity play in discussions about zoning and housing policy?
qaPairs.answer: This is kind of tricky. I think everybody deserves an equal shot at the American dream. However, I don't think people should be allowed to bring other people down. So, you know, if someone's homeless and they move into a Section 8 housing, that's a huge step up for them. But if you build a Section 8 complex in an affluent or even a middle class neighborhood, that brings other people down. And, you know, that's just how it is. And I think that if any developer that tears down affordable housing should have to build an equal number of new units to replace the old ones for the people that they kick out. But that said, I think certain people deserve to be closer to the front of the line for programs like this than others. Some of them, they make their living off of this. That's not right. So, you know, somebody that, if they're like a college student working two jobs and they need affordable housing, that's the kind of person we want. We don't want the person who, you know, got five kids with five different baby daddies, okay? No, that's not right. So, yeah, I think there should be some type of hierarchy for priorities when dealing with social equity and the access.

I Think higher density Has a It I think it's actually it's both You know when when there gets to be so many people Crammed into Small spaces they need You know you need more units But It can also have a negative effect If people get inconvenient especially by people that they see as Leeches people that just you know They're a piece of crap And you know not that just because report but because they choose to stay like that they don't do anything to To pick themselves up so And that has a negative effect on general opinion because when people see someone see a Program get taken advantage like that You know the their instant reaction is to say well, let's just cut it and that's not fair because there are people that that Legitimately need those programs and should be able to to access them so But I do think it it's more negative because it taxes the system overall From start to finish. I mean you're talking about Permits and construction areas and Dirt and debris for months or years, you know and jackhammers going people don't want to live like that, so Yeah, I think overall it has a negative effect
qaPairs.question: Does Higher density housing have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Higher density housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I Think if there was a level playing field for everybody again. I mentioned this earlier if Everybody's house was just basically the same I mean at least you I don't know you could have different designs and that kind of thing but square footage You know the size of the house and that kind of if everybody was on a level playing field. I think more people would Would be on board with it they would know that there's a what to expect they could you know plan for things You know somebody that lives in a single-family neighborhood with detached homes You know and all of a sudden some Tall building comes in and blocks their view to the I don't know some landscape or river or whatever you know That that'll decrease support However if You know if you want to To equalize things I think more people Would be able to get behind something like that But You know rich people don't want to move into a neighborhood where they don't know in five years There's going to be a ghetto next door and You know same thing with people that are less fortunate They don't want to move in the low-income neighborhood only to have some Bouchifide tower go in there raising property taxes cost living you know Their rents go up, and then next thing you know Some greedy developer wants to come in knock down their building and put up a new one So I Think if there was if everybody lived in like had a an equal playing field That would increase The support for upzoning
qaPairs.question: What might lead to increases or decreases in Support for Upzoning, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

qaPairs.answer: I'm pretty confident that Section 8 housing leads to changes for upzoning, and depending where you live at, it'll be good or bad. I think people either love it or hate it. There's no in between. If it's a good neighborhood and they're bringing in Section 8, then it's going to be, they're going to lose support. If it's an industrial area or one that's already low income, it may have a short-term positive effect because people will be able to have a place they can afford. But it would be pretty strong either way.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Section 8 housing lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Section 8 housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I'm very confident that middle class families would increase support for upzoning. It's true they would increase some traffic, congestion, that kind of thing, but they would have the money to be able to afford to upgrade things like infrastructure, utilities, school systems, first responders, hospitals, that could accommodate the influx of people. And overall, I think that would be a very positive effect because when you have strong middle class neighborhoods that can afford to go out to eat and take a vacation, go to the movies, everybody benefits from that and the effect from that is pretty strong.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Middle-class families lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Middle-class families â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: It depends if there's going to be something the community is going to benefit from. If the developer offers to put in new roads, expand the school, and upgrade the sewer system in return for the new zoning, it could be a positive effect that's felt pretty quick. I mean, people would, even though it wouldn't be in place, they could see it on the horizon. They would know that it's coming. At the same time, let's say they do that, but when they do that, they have to install a bigger pump because there's more taxing of the sewer system, and that takes more energy to run, which in turn raises utility costs. That's something that wouldn't be felt until longer term, but overall, I think people pretty much have their minds made up. When you say upzoning, they automatically know what that means, and they have their feelings already set. For somebody that's totally dead set against it, I don't know that you could ... Well, you might be able to pay them to change their mind, but short of that, I don't see them giving an inch. People on the other side of it, same thing. They want the housing really bad. This might be their only shot at ever getting a roof over their head, so they're going to fight like hell for it, too. I think most of the effects are ... Most of the negative effects, I think, are felt, actually felt later on after things are in place, but people have their minds made up before they go into things like that.
qaPairs.question: Is the effect of Positive vs Negative Impacts on Support for Upzoning immediate, or does it take time to develop? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Positive vs Negative Impacts â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think it would add some support in some areas for upzoning, but I think a larger shift is what it would take to really move the needle. You're going to have to make everybody confident that they're not going to be upsold or downsold either way. That's understandable. I'd say let's do affordable housing, but it has to be comparable to what's in the neighborhood. It can't stick out like a sore thumb. If there's nice single-family detached with well-kept lawns, don't be putting up some under-blocked building that looks like an eyesore, because no matter how much affordability that is, people are going to hate it, except for the inhabitants. I think a shift in evening out the properties themselves among the population would have a strong positive effect and support.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Housing Affordability lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Housing Affordability â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Yeah, it's a good relationship for short term. People get the housing they want for the prices they can afford, but that's not usually how the entire surrounding community feels about it. But in the beginning, there's a strong connection because people, you know, they just got a roof over their head. But in the long run, I just have a feeling that if it's, you know, not a middle class or above standard, then it's a very strong negative effect. And it's felt through the entire community because people, you know, they had, were living, their lives were fine before this happened. So that would be a very strong effect. I can tell you myself that would, you'd get a strong reaction from me if that happened.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Short-term Benefits and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Short-term Benefits â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: There is actually a strong support for upzoning. The relationship between prosperity and support for it is actually closer than what you might think, but only because the rich people usually think in long term. They see a new Section 8 building go up in a prime neighborhood, they're thinking five years down the road how they're going to be able to kick the people out, knock down the basketball courts and put up a new tower. So it's ironic in that sense, but immediately there's a disconnect, especially if it's a nice neighborhood. People just know what that's going to do to their values, to their lives in general is going to change. That's not what they signed up for in the beginning, and they have a right to be mad. So yeah, I think if you're rich and you can hold out until a rich developer comes in and increases everybody's property value by putting up a new tower, I think it's a more negative effect depending what social class you're from.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Prosperity and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Prosperity â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Uh, small changes and it, it can, I think in certain areas, uh, depending what side of the political spectrum those people are on, you know, if they're liberal, uh, they, you could have a, an entire neighborhood that's all for, um, affordable housing. And again, if you're in a more conservative neighborhood, um, you know, that's, uh, or, or just one where there's high net worth individuals, yeah, they're, they're going to fight you every step of the way. Um, but it can, you know, especially if, um, in a state like Florida where it could be seasonal during the, the summer, Florida's liberal population swells or in the winter, and then in the summer it goes down. So, um, and in that case it, it could, it, you know, that it could be like the tide going in and out, um, that would be an interesting, uh, uh, interesting study to figure that out. But, uh, I think overall, um, small changes in population size wouldn't have that big of an effect.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in City Population Size lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: City Population Size â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Yeah, I don't think it would take much for small changes to upset somebody's way of life. And when that happens, it's almost always negative. I can't see how somebody would, I don't know, to me I think of something like going to the grocery store and instead of always having an empty lane to check out in right away, now all the lanes have five or six people in, you know. You go to a restaurant or something and now there's a waiting line, you know, or not. That could be a change too, but if people, you know, if they start ripping out like, I don't know, a nice park and they start putting up basketball courts, people don't want to see that. That would be something that would probably be enough to make a lot of people not support upzoning or a baseball field. That's another thing, which wouldn't necessarily be a big change to me, you know, that would be a small change, but it would make a big difference. So I think that would have a, I think small changes do have a strong effect.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Neighborhood quality lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Neighborhood quality â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think that depends on what part of the country you live in you can if you're in New York City You're gonna get a lot of pushback if you don't have green written all over Your project whereas, you know some place that's maybe Republican like Texas or something they don't care what you do, you know, if you you tell them you're putting up a building and you're gonna make a business out of it and bring tax dollars or bring jobs, they'll let you do anything. So I think it's a strong effect either way, but it depends on depends on the area
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between greenhouse gases and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: greenhouse gases â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: That depends on the community itself. If it's Section 8 going into a neighborhood that's already filled with Section 8, I don't know that that's going to cause a strong effect, but gentrification alone, yes, has a very strong effect, and it's on both sides. The people moving into a neighborhood, they see it as they're getting a deal. You move somebody, well, take New York. An apartment in Midtown or SoHo is going to cost you five, six grand for a studio. You move uptown above 99th or something, and prices come down, but you're still in the city, and you're okay with that. However, you're saving money, but by you moving there, you actually pushed out someone that was paying less money. Now, to the people in that neighborhood, you're the reason their rents are going up, not down. It's a very strong effect. For the people that are part of the gentrification, it's positive. For the people that are not part of the gentrification, the lower income, it's a negative.
qaPairs.question: Does Gentrification have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Gentrification â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think an increase in tax base would lead to more support for upzoning if they were moving in middle class people or above. However, the opposite is true if it's low income. I think that's a strong negative effect because middle class and above people can afford to pay more taxes to upgrade the things needed to accommodate the rise in population. People that move into section 8 cannot.
qaPairs.question: Would small changes in Tax Base lead to noticeable changes in Support for Upzoning, or would it take larger shifts? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Tax Base â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think that would be a negative effect in support for that. Congestion means people have longer commute times to and from work and that is a big no-no so that would be a strong negative effect.
qaPairs.question: How confident are you that changes in Traffic Congestion lead to changes in Support for Upzoning? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Traffic Congestion â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: Homelessness has a strong negative effect for upzoning. That is probably one of the most, that's probably one of the biggest concerns people have on upzoning is especially if it's going to be a section 8 building, people worry that there's going to be homeless camps set up. And they don't, you know, that is a definite no-no, especially if it's a neighborhood with lots of families. People are scared for their kids and their quality of life. It's just not, just not good.
qaPairs.question: Does Homelessness have a positive or negative effect on Support for Upzoning, and how significant is this effect? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Homelessness â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think social equity and support for upzoning, there's definitely a strong connection there, you know, because we're not being honest if we think there's not a huge divide between the haves and the have-nots in society. And I think that's the general theory behind affordable housing and upzoning, but sometimes I think they only see that, you know, they don't see the things that the negative consequences, you know, like increased congestion, tax, utilities like that, you know, schools, hospitals, that kind of thing. But then they, it's like they just, once the neighborhood's been demolished, they just, they look for another place to try again. And I think that has an increasingly negative effect. But for right now, I think social equity and support for upzoning share a close relationship.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Social Equity and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Social Equity â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think they're strongly connected. There's always a way for someone to make money in real estate. Whether or not that's positive or negative depends which side of the transaction you're on.
qaPairs.question: How would you describe the relationship between Replacement of Affordable Housing and Support for Upzoning? Is it a strong or weak connection? Does it have a positive effect (increasing it) or a negative effect (decreasing it)? How strong is this effect?
qaPairs.shortText: Relationship: Replacement of Affordable Housing â†’ Support for Upzoning

qaPairs.answer: I think an equal playing field among the structures themselves is key to gaining support. The physical appearance and size of the properties much match the size and decor of the surroundings. By doing this people don't have to worry about being upsold or down sold.
qaPairs.question: What might lead to increases or decreases in Upzoning policies, and how significant are these effects? Please also indicate if these influences are positive (increasing) or negative (decreasing).

Yes

You have two options for answering questions: voice recording or typing. For voice recording, press the microphone button (ðŸŽ¤) or the Space key to start recording. When finished, press the microphone button or Space key again to stop. You can also press ESC to cancel. The system will automatically transcribe and submit your response after recording. Would you like to try voice recording now?
Not really, I prefer typing.

For text input, click the message icon (ðŸ’¬) to switch modes. Type your response in the text box. Press Ctrl+Enter or click the send button (âž¤) to submit. You can press ESC to clear your text. Would you like to try text input now?
Okay

You can switch between voice and text modes at any time. In voice mode, the microphone button will show as red when recording is active. During transcription, you'll see 'Transcribing your speech...' and your answer will be automatically submitted once ready. Feel comfortable with the system now?
